review.cons: Cons – Soemtimes the associates are pushed so much to hit benchmark they just end up quitting.
review.advice-to-management: Yes, I would recommend this company to a friend

review.title: “Great place to work”
review.pros: Pros – they offer good insurance and they take care of their employees
review.cons: Cons – insurance deductible the hiring to make an Overstock employee permanent takes more than 1-2 even 3 years
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The Leadership is really good to people that followed it other leads supposed to followed the example to our associates but they dont and associates talk about it..

review.title: “I feel that O.co is a great place to work and also a great contributor our local, national and global community.”
review.pros: Pros – It is not just a job. It is a community of people that do amazing things like (1) donated 80 thousand pounds of food to 2010 holiday food drive in Salt Lake City, (2) along with our amazing customers, provided Wounded Warrior Project with hundreds of thousands of dollars of support in 2010 and 2011; (3) through Worldstock, have provided about $70 million in funds to aritsans in developing economies over the past 10 years. So I feel like my time at work counts for more than just putting money in my pocket.
review.cons: Cons – I think communication from management could be better. Changes happen and we dont always get an explanation of why.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Have more stand ups or figure out a way to have virtual stand ups so everyone can see and hear what is said.

review.title: “Love it!”
review.pros: Pros – I have grown very much personally and professionally here. I am constantly challenged and learning new things. If all else fails, it's great experience to place on a resume.
review.cons: Cons – Communication can be misunderstood, thus tasks may be executed improperly. The aftermath of that is dependent on the results once misunderstood communication has been shared.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Tough times calls for desperate measures. It's not always easy making the hard decisions. People will always be more willing to offer critism to someone else rather than look to themselves to see how they can better improve. It's always easier to blame the people on top. I believe that management is a strong group of people just trying to do the right thing for the company. Rather than just shooting down ideas because you feel like something won't work, try it first if there is no good reason not to. If it fails, then at least it was tried.

review.title: “Slow promotions and even slower raises. Bonuses suck.”
review.pros: Pros – The people here are great to work with and there is always work to do so sitting around is not an option.
review.cons: Cons – Senior leadership needs to worry less about suing other companies and more about being profitable. People getting promoted solely for sucking up yet being completely inept at any type of leadership.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Fire yourselves and take a 1010 course on management.

review.title: “This is a company that never quite matured.”
review.pros: Pros – Folks here are friendly.Folks try very hard to get their jobs done despite a strong culture of micromanagement.
review.cons: Cons – NepotismPoor compensationShort-sighted planning ans strategyMiddle management does not last long unless they act as "yes men" to their executivesPoor ability to identify and follow best practicesThe CEO has a dog he brings into the office and he lets it wander around and sniff people.Extreme levels of dishonesty from the CEO and his direct reports.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Go back to "overstock.com", "o.co" has no brand recognition.Keep the customer service and the marketing departments completely separate.Start holding vendors accountable for services provided.Understand that as an internet retailer your core business depends on reliable IT service and your IT department has been gutted by poor wage raises and compensation.Concentrate on what you are doing good at, not on fads.An "open" work area environment is counterproductive when the office is so crowded.The CEO should quit micromanaging.

review.title: “Overstock.com is an example of how poor management affects sound business models”
review.pros: Pros – Great work/life balanceSalt Lake is a nice place to liveLot of tech resources available, fundamental business is soundPretty healthy gross margins and top line growth is impressive
review.cons: Cons – Very poor upper managementMiddle management is inexperiencedHorrendous expense managementAlmost all of the gross margin is lost due to irrational operating, marketing and G&A expensesOrganizations are redistributed too often, business strategies are transient and shakyNo strategic vision whatsoever, company has an identity crisis
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – There is a stark contrast in Overstock's management team. If you were to draw a line down the middle, you would see a group of bright, ambitious go-getters on one side and a group of execs with no real experience outside O.co on the other. Product innovation is virtually stagnant and capital management is poor. Overstock's story reads like a b-school case study of a company with sound fundamentals that's handcuffed by poor management.

review.title: “A lot of Potential”
review.pros: Pros – - Growing Company- Profitable- Work/life balance- Smart peers- Ability to do solve very complex problems
review.cons: Cons – - Senior Management very reactionary when making decisions- Not allowed to do things the right way, have to do what Senior Mgmt wants- Many of the leaders only have work experience at Overstock; not enough to know industry standards and best practices- Senior Management is over departments they should never even be allowed to get close to. (i.e. SVP of Customer Service also over Marketing)
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Start listening to your employees. This is the least bureaucratic bureaucracy out there. Just because you know a lot about one subject, does not mean you know a lot about everything else. Stop making decisions on an employees job when you know very little about what they do.

review.title: “Below average experience with hefty bureaucracy”
review.pros: Pros – Nice coworkers and one of the better views.
review.cons: Cons – The bureaucracy is insane. You practically have to get your hands stamped everytime you lift a finger to do something. Senior management is getting better, but it feels like only a handful are qualified to run a billion dollar business.Internal supporting technology is at least 10 years behind, and there is a tendency to just pay the most expensive bidder to make a problem go away.Most of the qualified merchandising talent has left in the past year. Most businesses are run by recently promoted lower level employees trying to not screw it up too badly. Everyone is scared to death of layoffs, which happen with no rhyme or reason. Did I mention the bonus structure is nearly non-existent?
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Fix your reviews process. It is pathetic. Everyone is afraid of more qualified employees taking their place. Low performers are given low goals that any baboon can reach, but high perfomers are given impossible goals to keep them in their place.Hire better. With good talent, you don't have to have pay a bunch of number crunchers and consultants to tell you how to run the business.Senior management spends zero time at ground level. The occasional 15 second hello in the hallway is useless. Middle level employees are at the mercy of the the kings and queens of their fiefdoms. There is no safe way to bubble up concerns privately.Spend one day a month sitting with employees, privately and at their desks You'll learn a lot more than you ever will talking to other management.Stop jumping on the next big thing every month. We need to get it right the first time. Non-stop training for processes that change every quarter kills productivity.

review.title: “Great place to work if you are okay with "cliques".”
review.pros: Pros – The pay seems to be competitive. The job can be fulfilling if you don't mind staying in the position you are hired in to.
review.cons: Cons – There can be a lot of drama in the Customer Care Department. If you try not to get involved in it you are seen as uncaring and you get passed up on a lot of opportunities.Most of the advancement seems to be within a certain type of crowd. If you aren't part of the crowd that "parties" with middle management you won't get far in the company. There is little support for an employee that works hard and knows the ins and outs of their position when their direct supervisor doesn't know how to do their job.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I would recommend taking a look at the team lead if the entire team seems to be falling behind.

review.title: “poor pay, micromanaging, poor communication”

The benefits are also pretty expensive and terrible (Select Health - I had an HSA - I paid $30 a month, deposited $50 a month with no monthly employer contribution)
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – give more advancement opportunities to those who have been there longer/worked hard, rather than hiring new, incompetent managers. give more monetary incentives (as opposed to embarrassing field-trip-esque 'concerts'). Monthly contributions to those with HSAs (customary at many smaller companies). Don't send out emails warning staff of spending "up to 15 minutes a day" on non-work sites - we are adults and we have BREAK TIME. Seriously, we can do our jobs too.

review.title: “Excellent company to work for but depends on which group you are in”

review.cons: Cons – Development group seems to be bloated at this point, not sure how that is going to play out in the near future.

review.title: “Great”

review.cons: Cons – I have no complaints at this time.

review.title: “Best job I've ever had.”

They are not limiting, and are sure to make it clear that your job is to advocate for the customer and make them happy. Making people happy is a job I like to do, and surely makes a job a lot easier.
review.cons: Cons – Some of the days surely become repetitive. Things may get old, but there is enough room for opportunity that once things really begin to become too repetitive you can move up or move teams or do something different, its amazing. review.title: “Great company Gone horribly WRONG”
review.pros: Pros – Health benefits are OKIt is a great place if you are a ski bum or if you like hiking the state of Utah, or simply because you have a higher reason not to leave the state of Utah.If you are good at selling ideas that sound good in meetings and love to have meetings from 8am to 6pm, this is the place for you. If you are crafty enough to arrange your work schedule around meetings, you can actually move from one meeting to another for a whole week, without actually performing any real job as long as you talk your way around the great projects or ideas that should be implemented and take down any new initiatives or real work done by others.Align yourself with the VP of Merch/marketing and you are done and don't ever go against any of the buyers.
review.cons: Cons – Toxic work environment, you can actually spent days without talking to anyone.No vision of the future at the leadership level.Every day there is a Fire drill kind of environment, where the only thing you do is take out fires (problems) and being careful not to be blamed for the causes of the problem.Patrick Byrne made a great idea a reality, sadly most of his time, ideas and money are spent in fighting everybody else with lawsuits (wallstreet, hedge funds, gary weiss,banks etc) and talking about naked short selling, which is in fact a problem, but not the cause of Overstock's stock price decline.So the company is headless in terms of direction and lacks vision of the future.Retention rate of employees is very low, the average time a person stays at Overstock is close to 1 year.There is no open communication channel from lower to upper management levels, last initiative was to set up a web interface to allow employees to voice their ideas, but the qualification process of the ideas is in the hands of the same people that truncate the communication to the decision person (Patrick Byrne).Great place if you love to spend your time in Facebook and Youtube, just make sure you have one of those 3M screen protectors, so no one can see from the side what you are doing.No retention strategy for talented employees.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – There is a lot of raw talent, at Overstock due to the location close to BYU and UofU, but it is not fully used because the culture prevalent at Overstock, makes people behave as Know it All's.Once these talented people get a hold of the business, they move to other positions leaving Overstock, without the knowledge because there is never a transition of tasks.Once someone is gone, all the experience and knowledge is gone.

review.title: “good place to work”

review.cons: Cons – many manual hurdles to still overcome.

review.title: “Overstock.comish”
review.pros: Pros – Family Atmosphere, food, fun, make friends, close to home, fish, plants, open areas,
review.cons: Cons – Some un-friendly co-workers, cheap coffee, and Bathrooms
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Improve, Improve, and Improve the company, systems, and atmosphere.

review.title: “Great company”
review.pros: Pros – Much scrutiny is given to potential employees, so good people are typically hired. Fast paced, fun environment. Great location right next to the mountains.
review.cons: Cons – Not a lot of vacation hours.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep it up.

review.title: “Great benifits, poor leadership.”
review.pros: Pros – The insurance benifits are superb.
review.cons: Cons – Don't try to get ahead in this company unless you are "in" with someone. Most promotions are based on personal feelings of team leads and supervisors, not you performance or capeabilities. Upper management has been hired from within, that means not many are qualified for the positions and almost all new projects and procedures are always a work in progress, and are usually at odds with the other departments. Working at the call center is a nightmare for the most part.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – When you say you are going to do something, DO IT! Some of your best employees are stuck because hiring managers hire for "Personality" rather than for their qualifications.

review.title: “Overstock.com is a Great Place to Work for Software Developers”
review.pros: Pros – Lot's of very smart developers who are dedicated to the professional growth of themselves and their colleagues.
review.cons: Cons – There are some disconnects between the business side and IT. Big surprise.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I don't have any advice for management that I haven't shared internally.

review.title: “Overstock understands leadership”
review.pros: Pros – It is a place to work where individual opinion is respected throughout all levels of the organizaion. They truly get leadership and recognize and foster leadership potential.
review.cons: Cons – A relatively young company so they are experiencing normal growing pains.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Systems and processes will become more important as the company continues to grow. Apply more resources in these arenas.

review.title: “Great place to work”
review.pros: Pros – Best job I have ever had. Everyone pulls their weight.
review.cons: Cons – The HR policies are a little immature.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The HR policies need to migrate towards a mature set of policies, rather than a stripped down non-inclusive set of policies (and benefits).

review.title: “Underwhelming position but ok if its the only company in SLC hiring.”
review.pros: Pros – Benefits, especially medical are second to none in terms of price and coverage.
review.cons: Cons – Technology is stagnant and not progressive. Marketing VP runs the company. Technology, though central to the business is secondary.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Hire more Junior developers to do the job since you really don't take advantage of the talent of the Senior Developers you employ.

review.title: “Overall decent place to work”
review.pros: Pros – Great people to work with.
review.cons: Cons – Lack of communication provided from executives. Underpaid
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Better communication.

review.title: “Not a friendly place to work”
review.pros: Pros – overstock has decent pay and benefits
review.cons: Cons – Management is incompetent. You have to kiss up to them to get any attention, the people that have moved up have done so because of that
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Quit your day jobs please

review.title: “Not bad... not GOOD, but not bad”
review.pros: Pros – The company is doing well. There's no threat of a lay off coming any time soon... that I know of.
review.cons: Cons – The working conditions are pretty bad. There's no private space at all. Desks are jammed together and cramped. Benefits could use a LOT of work.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Tell us what you want from us. Tell the directors and team leads to communicate what you want from us more effectively.

review.title: “Copywriter”
review.pros: Pros – Great benefits for all employees
review.cons: Cons – Corporate culture is really bad
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – None

review.title: “"OK"”
review.pros: Pros – Nice people, fun atmosphere, challenging work. Work that you do is noticed because the group is so small. Very smart people work for the company.
review.cons: Cons – Bad pay, no stock options. Managers have experience but no degree above a bachelors degree. Directors try to take credit for the work there employees do.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – If you want to get more talented people to work for the company, you need to make a Masters degree minimum to be a manager.

review.title: “Senior Software Engineer”
review.pros: Pros – All open source environment. Linux workstations.
review.cons: Cons – Too many homegrown frameworks that are sub-par.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Layoff the homegrown frameworks.

review.title: “Great Place!”
review.pros: Pros – Very fast pace keeps you busy and prevents boredom.
review.cons: Cons – Very fast paced and pay is mediocre.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Educate yourself with exactly what the people or departments do.

review.title: “Take incoming calls from customer regarding multiple issues and attempt to resolve the issues.”
review.pros: Pros – Very laid back atmosphere and very understanding about personal situations. Easy to move up and a growing company.
review.cons: Cons – Dealling with unreasonable customers. Customer don't always take the initiative to read all of policies and expect that because of this we should make exceptions.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the great work without all of you everything that runs so smothely at overstock wouldn't be possible.

review.title: “Love my job but wish I could support on a small income.”
review.pros: Pros – 1. The people.2. Great company to learn and grow.3. Freedom to work on a flexible schedule.4. Upper management (Patrick & Stormy) pushing you to grow.5. Great involvement with community.
review.cons: Cons – 1. Salary to low for work.2. Not only having pride for our CS department but projecting that in others.3. Not receiving praise for my supervisor, only hearing the negative. Hearing that I am an important part of the company from him, knowing and hearing it from the upper management.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – To let your employees know the importance of them with higher salaries and or hourly wage, most of the employees are single parents or living paycheck to paycheck. Giving praise where praise is deserved, advised supervisors and TL to give so they might be able to receive more effective work and dedication. I love my job and I do not think of Overstock.com as a job but as a career.

review.title: “Challenging yet rewarding.”
review.pros: Pros – Interesting technology and smart people make it a dynamic and challenging place to work. The company likes to promote from within and gives plenty of lateral movement opportunities. Management encourages people to step out of they're domains and learn new angles or work in different departments.
review.cons: Cons – The pace is very fast and at times too fast. People can easily get driven into the ground and burn out if they're not careful. Some technology mandates have seemed more political in nature rather then based on needs. Many options are simply disregarded for reasons that don't always make sense.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – We've been extremely aggressive with hiring and a lot of balls in the air . The infrastructure and organizational problems are growing as well.

review.title: “LOVE it!!”
review.pros: Pros – The growth potential is outstanding at this company, I feel as though everything i do is recognized and appreciated. It makes coming to work everyday worth it!
review.cons: Cons – It seems as though some changes that occur leave some feeling up in the air for a while, which is a cause of stress.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Remembering that changes implemented need to consider all involved.

review.title: “Excellent place to work!”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com pays higher than any call center I've come across. The benefits are excellent! Overstock.com is #2 best customer service, It shows in the way us employees are treated here. We are treated with respect, there's lost of communication and that in turn affects the customer service that is provided to all of our customers! This company has lots of room for advancement, you really have to apply yourself and make sure you voice where you want to go.
review.cons: Cons – Definitely high school like atmosphere here. But that is expected with a call center. Definitely something easy to get over though.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – This company has the most amazing foundation and structure. I see this company moving higher and higher and becoming more and more efficient. Save the paper clips. Keep doing what your doing, it's working.

review.title: “Worst place for qa-you are a nobody living on the whim of your supervisor-IT department runs the show - dictatorship”
review.pros: Pros – Possibly a place to learn some skills, skiing & politics. If you are want to live in utah maybe one of the limited choices. If you do't have a job take it as a last resort -then leave as soon as you get a better offer job or get fed up.
review.cons: Cons – IT/dev runs the place - all other divisions run scared - if your not in IT then accept your inferior position - no career path for qa/ba's/business - just work & get paid half decently - but you'll be a little clog for ever - they fired/demoted all the qa management and want you to be agile (under it department)-there are a few guys in top management who are there for life bec of relations w/the ceo-and middle management by another bunch of guys -also hordes of h1 guys with their appls screwed up & stuck
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Wait for better times in the market and then realize the folly of your ways. if toyota can be felled - you are way easier to the dustbin of business history

review.title: “Hip, cool environment.”
review.pros: Pros – The celebrities.Friendly, open techie environmentOpportunity to contribute to the success of OverstockGet paid to ride your bike to work
review.cons: Cons – InbreedingLimited levels of work experienceOnly the strong surviveTop Down Management Style
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Empower employees. Hold people accountable for action or lack thereof. Promote teamwork.

review.title: “I wouldn't recommend it to others”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com is good about it's reasonable work schedules for salaried employees, depending on the job position. Overstock, from my experience, has not tried to take advantage of it's salaried employees by overworking them or expecting that they work 60 hour weeks. There are a few company sponsored programs that allow for growth that are given to it's employees. The company also offers a floating holiday which can be taken 1 of 4 days which allows a bit more flexibility in planning time off. The view from the corporate office has a beautiful outlook at the mountains.
review.cons: Cons – Compensation for work is somewhat non-competitive when compared to the field. To rub salt in that wound, the company is rather open about the fact that it is intending to hire many new members, making it obvious that the lack of pay is not due to the fact that the company does not have the funds for it but rather, a choice made by the management.The process by which an employee is let go is obscure without offering any insight into what happened or how you yourself can avoid a similar fate. Office politics run rampant, and while employees are openly judged bi-yearly by their managers with little ability to speak out against an unfair rating, they have no ability to rate their managers in return, or even speak out against a bad one. In addition, the system on which they are rated is undefined until the moment that they are rated, leaving one wondering exactly what they will be judged on at this particular moment in time.Parking is atrocious at the corporate office, with not nearly enough parking spaces provided for the employees, and most new employees have to park in the overflow lot and take a shuttle to work.While the company does provide some web courses for people to take that it touts are worth college credits, these are primarily a bone thrown to it's customer service department, and useless to anyone who already has a college degree and is looking to expand their education.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – It has been said a few times that one of the realizations that happened with the overstock management was that it's employees were valuable and paying for ones that do good work was worth the extra money. Lately these words seem to have rung hollow, and instead it feels more as if the employees are yet another piece of overstocked merchandise that when it can't be utilized is simply thrown to the wayside.Provide more accountability upward as opposed to simply in one direction. Allow employees to have an anonymous voice for whether or not they feel like they're being treated fairly by their managers.Allow more insight into the reasons why people are let go so other people can avoid making the same mistakes. And if there is no good reason why someone was fired, then perhaps that's an indication that they were fired for the wrong reasons.Get more parking spaces.Offer real opportunities for growth, not just to the people working for the CS department but across the company.

review.title: “Warehouse worker.”
review.pros: Pros – People are friendly and nice.
review.cons: Cons – Low pay for warehouse workers, it seems
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the good work.

review.title: “A late phase startup struggling to be profitable. Lots of smart dedicated people with reasonable working hours.”
review.pros: Pros – If you like to Ski, hike some of the best in the country is only 20-30 min from the office and they are in need of many Java developers and QA. You will not get overworked unless you want. The non management employees are all nice people and fun to work with. Most are highly skilled but underutilized. The pay for developers is fair for the middle of the country.- Housing (renting) is very reasonable and very negotiable in SLC area.- Great outdoor activities very close to work- Traffic, what traffic?- Easy to live 10-15 min from office- Great Skiing, Hiking very close to everything.- Everything is 30min away including Park City which is a very commutable distance.- Other tech companies are moving into SLC such as Google, EBay, Goldman Sachs, Microsoft
review.cons: Cons – The company sells its self as a mature company with lots of potential for growth and profitability yet Sr Management is unexperienced and behaves like an early stage startup. An example of this how often they re-organise which is about as often as the wind changes direction. You just might get moved out to SLC and find yourself re-orginized out of a job with no return ticket. The separation is two weeks pay + unused vacation.- Don't sell you house if you are moving to SLC from afar, rent it.- Once you start, forget what they told you during the interview process. They are not looking for any constructive criticism or input for improvement to their systems. Keep your head low, do you job as asked and no more.- If you have not been there for 4-5+ years your an outsider. Remember this.- Vacation time is 15 days but that includes your sick days. Don't get sick or go to work when your sick.- 401k does not start for 6 months- Do not make yourself known at the SVP level. If they don't like you or have a bad day, your gone quicker than a roll of the dice in Vegas. It does not matter how much value you have added in the past.- Winter pollution inversions are just nasty. Worst air in the country for this entire week.- If you have kids the public schools in UT (Other than Park City) are about as bad as they get. So you will have to look into one of the two high end public schools both of which are about $15k/year/child. The other private schools seem to only be a bit better than the public schools but nothing like the schools on either coast and are religiously oriented.- The moving bonus requires you to stay for a year or pay it back.- Most of the upper management have only worked at Overstock or perhaps one other company after getting out of school. They do not understand how the rest of the world operates have have a very ignorant view of it.- Huge culture shock if you are not a member of the XXX Church.- If you are a really smart creative person, you will not have the opportunity to express yourself here.- If you need a job for a year it might be a place to work until the economy gets better.- You might want to not accept any "moving bonus" which would give you the flexibility of leaving when you want.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – There are some very smart people working for you but they are not allowed to challenge the "old timers" without fear of reprisal. This comes from the top down. Several of your upper managers (business and technology) are not qualified to be leading at the level they are at. Promotion from within is a great idea but just because someone has been there for many years does not qualify them to lead. A mature company needs a mature management team which does not make emotional knee jerk decisions.Have an outsider evaluate your Sr management team and help you determine if they are the proper people to run you business. The current team will/is failing you and will not allow you grow as you would like and need.

review.title: “Overstock Employee”
review.pros: Pros – Good balance between work and life with a laid back environment. Middle Management is very competent and helpful. Most people are easy to work with and very knowledgeable.
review.cons: Cons – Few opportunities to move up unless you are good friends with executives. A fear of speaking out against ideas that come from senior exectutives.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – No clear path for promotion opportunities.

review.title: “Needs some real help . . .”
review.pros: Pros – Very good about giving time off, even if there is no PTO available. The people who do regular functions for the company are fun to work with and very competent in their work.
review.cons: Cons – Upper management wants it to be the best company to work for, but a lot of things will have to change before that happens. Extreme culture of nepotism and cronyism. Many cases of "failing up"; employees performing so poorly that they are moved up because no one wants to work with them, consequently, Overstock has very, very poor management. If you are educated, smart or hardworking, and want to advance in a career, avoid Overstock.com like cancer. Unless you are good friends with management, you'll never move up or get paid an appropriate wage. I could write a 1000 page book on what's wrong with this company. It goes without saying, this company will never even make the top 100 companies to work for.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Management at Overstock has a reputation and culture of not taking advice from subordinates. When they say they will, it's all lip service.

review.title: “Opportunities to make a difference. Compensation doesn't reflect performance or responsibility.”
review.pros: Pros – Good hours, mostly good people to work with, ample opportunities to make a difference and affect change, good exposure to senior managers, flexible work schedule, laid back culture, good/smart opinions are valued, young and energetic colleagues
review.cons: Cons – Many people in other groups are apathetic/unwilling to put in the time to do a good job. Some of the executive management appear to lack the experience and knowledge to run a billion dollar company.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Mentor/train/promote and pay your best people and the people who actually care to make a difference. Without your top performers this company will have a difficult, it not impossible time, staying profitable.

review.title: “What they're doing wrong...”
review.pros: Pros – Diverse, plenty of opportunities to grow or try something new, some very good managers, mainly in IT and Merchandising, great people to work with for the most part.
review.cons: Cons – Ridiculous amounts of money spent on moving people, I've heard rumors of 6 figure moves coming up next year and I don't understand the reasoning behind them. It's a huge waste of money the vast majority of the time, and there have been cases where my department has moved one month, only to move back the next! We should have stayed with our 6 floors, but now we may be moving to a warehouse...how much will that area cost to build out, and will that be enough room for us now that we are growing steadily?Management: the vast majority of managers, especially in Marketing, are the WORST when it comes to communicating with their teams, us underlings. Of course when a project deadline is approaching the communication is fine (Get it DONE!), but when moves are coming up, hiring new people, we usually don't hear about it until the day before which is a joke. There are also a lot of people who come up with some great ideas, of course they don't get the recognition for them, their manager or (most often) executive does. This is something I like to call an executive "stab in the back" versus what we should be getting, and executive "pat on the back". One person in particular is notorious for this, but specifics shouldn't be necessary.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – TALK to your people, recognize those that actually DO the work, we're all sick of people playing favorites for whatever reason, stop wasting money on needless moves and start planning (realistically) on where we're going to get the space some departments need, I really don't think the warehouse is a good idea.

review.title: “Salaries @ Overstock”
review.pros: Pros – I love everything about working at Overstock except my pay rate. As long as I can receive frequent pay increases to get me up to or keep me at norms I would stay here for a long time.
review.cons: Cons – I am considerably lower than industry standards for what I do. Though I love it here, it is enough to make me look for employment elsewhere. I am in software development btw.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – See the pros.

review.title: “Could be better, could be worse.”
review.pros: Pros – Semi-decent pay, good people, good benefits, seemingly decent job security.
review.cons: Cons – Did not get a raise last year and my cost of living has tripled. I've been passed over for a well deserved promotion more than once.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Please give raises to those who have worked hard to earn it.

review.title: “"Lateral Move" Anyone?”
review.pros: Pros – The culture here is great, everyone is accepted and pretty much everyone from every walk of life has or will work here.I feel respected and like I really do have a family here.Opportunities for advancement are everywehere. I started out in customer service and was promoted right out of training.Good benefits, lots of PTO, easy to get time off (as long as it's not 4th quarter :) very flexible with schedules, they have worked around my "single mom schedule" countless times.Many new learning opportunities and easy to get feedback where it's needed.There is a lot of overtime opportunities during the holidays.Many company sponsored events, Lagoon day, concerts, parties. Also lots of fun things always going on in the office.
review.cons: Cons – Sometimes they go on what seems like "firing sprees" and you don't know why or who they are targeting. It makes you nervous for weeks that you're next.Bonuses need to make sense. You do mediocre business one year and get a huge bonus and then the next year, your business exceeds everyone's expectations and your bonus is 1/3 of what it was last year(??).Upper management has a habit of holding meetings where they tell you how amazing you did and how much money you made for them and in the very next breath, they will tell you how they're cutting PTO hours or how there's not going to be any raises this year. Good thing we made all that money for them... The pat on the back is getting old, we have families to raise too.You don't get paid the standard even with the cost of living constantly rising. I know many people in customer service that have had to go on food stamps and utility assistance.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Tell us WHY you are doing what you're doing if you can. It makes people insecure and slighted to always be in the dark.It's nice to hear how much money we have made or how good we did in a survey, but maybe you could start paying the "little guys" a living wage since we're the roof of your Grecian Temple.

review.title: “It's a good company”
review.pros: Pros – -A lot of good people working here.-It's a solid company with a bright future.-Top level management seems very solid
review.cons: Cons – -My job could easily be done from a remote location, but that's not permitted.-Sick days should be allotted along with traditional PTO because w/o sick days people don't want to waste their vacation time because they're not feeling well, so they come into work sick and get other sick as well (I'm guilty of that because I never seem to have enough PTO)-Awful visibility into bonus structure, so it doesn't serve as the effective motivator that it could be - I feel there is a lot of missed potential there.-Merch hiring from CS is very common which provides for cheap labor but the level or professionalism can suffer as a result - seems like a good short term ROI strategy but I question the long term viability of real improvement.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – -My Cons list could use some attention and there are some easy wins there.-VPN access with remote office locations permitted.-Sick days in addition to regular PTO-Clear bonus structure with clear visibility

review.title: “One opinion of Overstock as a place to work.”
review.pros: Pros – With few exceptions, everyone I work with genuinely loves working here. They are all hard workers and knowledgeable concerning their job functions. Most of the people here have worked their way up and are familiar with the business processes to complete their assigned tasks. They are fair in all aspects of work.
review.cons: Cons – At times it is difficult to determine just how much my contribution is valued. I don't need a consistent pat on the back but a monthly pow wow would be very helpful to assess just where I and my team mates are with management.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – enforce monthly team meetings. I know some don't like them, but it's better to have all team members know where they stand in the company than to have them go about their daily duties wondering if their contribution is meaningful.

review.title: “For the most part I do love my job”
review.pros: Pros – I love what I do and I like the people I work with. Its good pay in comparison to other jobs out there.
review.cons: Cons – I think upper management could be alot more supportive of customer service. Their snide remarks don't help when we are busting our ass and working over time to get stuff done is not appreciated. We're the best team there is and we get no praise.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Drop the attitudes. Don't be hypocrites.

review.title: “I take orders and set up returns. Help our customers!”
review.pros: Pros – Great people, great atmosphere, and great pay and benefits! Its a great job.
review.cons: Cons – have to have a doc note for everyday you take off because sick.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I love working here

review.title: “It's Ok”
review.pros: Pros – Benefits are really nice. The only benefits that have been better that I have had has been with the Military which the Benefits are free.
review.cons: Cons – Work a whole bunch for the same pay as a fast food server while the Executives get paid over six digits a year.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Give raises please we need to feed our families too. Do not let certain employees get away with everything because they are special.

review.title: “Overstock.com company loyalty”
review.pros: Pros – Stable, growing company. Very loyal teams and low turnover. The feel of the corporate office is that everyone is very devoted to their job, to the company, and very busy.
review.cons: Cons – I never considered myself a workaholic before working at overstock, but I find myself working through lunches, staying late... etc. Sometimes this is a high-stress job.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The leadership would be wise to listen to feedback and specific advice from the little people in the trenches. Overstock hires thinkers, and encourages them to be proactive - they could take better advantage of the creative intelligence of the underlings.

review.title: “My 2 cents”
review.pros: Pros – Great Salary. Easy to approach Management. If you can get to the right people they are willing to listen to your ideas. Teams are very open and work well together. Little politics around.
review.cons: Cons – Headquaters are in Salt Lake City and it is difficult to attract talent to the area.PTO is lacking behind what other companies are offering.Lots of incompetent people hiding in the mix and they are difficult to remove despite providing facts.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – 1. Hire better trained project managers. It is a crucial role in making projects successful and very careful thought should be given as to who is given the role. Just cause someone is good at talking or is presentable does not necessarily make them good PMs.2. Listen to Team leads more on what is important for their respective department. They are your nerve center on how the company is doing.3. Promoting from within is important however every once in a while bring in outside talent to keep up with the industry. There are several departments that are lacking in this.

review.title: “Great place to work, still lots of opportunities to make a difference”
review.pros: Pros – - Challenging and interesting work- Exciting, leading-edge technology- Wonderful people to work with- Very little political nonsense- Truly a fun place to work
review.cons: Cons – - CEO is distracted- Unbudgeted spending- Management is not good at planning ahead- Not a lot of "gray hair" running the business
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – - The whole exposée on the Facebook relationships between journalists and fund managers was a complete embarrassment to Overstock. It looks like we are trying to distract people or hide something from them, and it comes off looking childish. We should be focused on running the company and staying out of the mud. "Never wrestle with a pig, you get dirty; and besides, the pig likes it." - George Bernard Shaw- Lawsuits are not a revenue stream.- We waste so much time, energy and money with all the moves we do around here. Build the same cubicles, offices and conference rooms on every floor. When it's time to move, the only expense will be cardboard boxes for people to carry their things to their new desk that looks exactly like the old one they just left. No more knocking down walls, running electrical, networking, and so on.

review.title: “Pay more”
review.pros: Pros – It's a laid back company that listens to it's employees ideas.
review.cons: Cons – Their pay compensation isn't anywhere near other companies. Recognition is few and far between.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – People only do what they are paid to do. Are you getting the work you need to keep this company in the high numbers for customer care?

review.title: “overstock”
review.pros: Pros – laid back peoplesimple jobwe get rewarded for doing our every day jobmost managers wont unless there willing to doitthey like to cross train for every thing
review.cons: Cons – we have an idea wats going on but it can always changeone manager tells you one thing then another has you do it the opposite
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – comunicate more frequntly and do the best they can to keep the plan as close to the original as posible its a pain to be told 1 is wen ur leaving then as your walking out they change it to later people make plans for rides and other stuff

review.title: “I've always loved working here”
review.pros: Pros – -Having a CEO that walks around and asks what you're up to so he knows his business from the ground up.-Having a CEO with a social conscience-Upper management that have senses of humor-Good health benefits- in over 4 years there's only been one time our insurance has said "no" (and I'm still working on getting that yes)-Move up from within! You can start out on the phones but if you learn everything you can, you can end up being a decision maker one day.
review.cons: Cons – -Sometimes if you're the person doing your job well and not causing problems, you're the one that's overlooked. (Squeaky wheel gets the grease you know)-Pay rarely matches what most others make at other places. I've always said "you have to really want to work here"....cause it won't be for the pay, but there's so many other trade offs that make it worthwhile. Still, it would be nice to make industry standard
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – There's a general feeling sometimes that only "the beautiful people" get plucked from a crowd and taught how to be "the next big thing" while others fight their way up the ladder. Although many of us know there's a lot of determination and drive that's looked at it does seem (quite often actually) that positions are created for the beautiful people while everyone else waits for a job to post so they can have the opportunity for the spotlight, to toot their own horn and a have chance for advancement.This may not be the case- but it's the perception, and that's what needs to be managed.

review.title: “Overstock ROCKS!!!”
review.pros: Pros – Patrick Byrne is one of the most caring, Knowledgeable people I have ever worked for. I feel that this company actually cares and acknowledges the fact that I have a family, and Family comes first.
review.cons: Cons – MORE LOCATIONS! Other than that, I LOVE IT!!!!!!!!!!
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – There is no advice I feel I can give at this time. The company I work for is the BEST and I never want to work anywhere else. I hope to move up in the company when I graduate with a business degree. WOOT WOOT!

review.title: “I am proud to work at Overstock.com.”
review.pros: Pros – Great and fun environment. Good benefits. Great people. Exciting opportunities. Company pride.
review.cons: Cons – Too stressful at times. Low pay for some positions. Politics.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the great work!

review.title: “An annoying job with a good company.”
review.pros: Pros – It is a good environment to work in and relatively relaxed for the type of work involved. The pay is good and the job is stable.
review.cons: Cons – It is still retail customer service. Most of the cons are to do with the work not the actual company. The job does get rather stressfull during the holidays and has little time off, right when most would like to be spending more time with their familys; an unfortunate effect of working in retail.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Just keep up the good work. The fact that the company is doing well reduces the anxiety we wold otherwise feel.

review.title: “little experience, ergo little feedback.”
review.pros: Pros – I get to take excellent care of the customer and I love that!
review.cons: Cons – Information isn't widely shared, but the attitude doesn't reflect that.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – go on with your bad self

review.title: “Overstock.com - A great place to work!”
review.pros: Pros – Great opportunities to cross train in different areas of the business. Progressive environment that encourages innovation.
review.cons: Cons – Communication between departments can be poor. The result is many reports, and processes are duplicated. Projects are occasionally developed without the input of all the stakeholders.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – 1. The department of excellence needs to work more with the management of the department they are directed to evaluate.2. Some of the process engineers are duplicating work done by the departments they are analyzing.3. Take any business areas that are not performing off life support.4. Focus on core competencies: Internet retailing. Taking on the role of a travel agent, realtor and car sales person might not be in line with these competencies. If these are good business ideas maybe they should be developed as standalone businesses. If they prove to be successful business models consider bringing them into the fold.

review.title: “A great place to work, with only a few dodgy management decisions.”
review.pros: Pros – Salary, benefits, promotion opportunities and the general population are all above average. Your workload is quite reasonable and it's a fine place to make a living.
review.cons: Cons – There's a lot of seasonal hiring and when the layoffs come around, some of the decisions seem arbitrary. Many good employees are at a risk for loosing their jobs and a lot of sub par employees seem to stick around much longer than you'd expect. There's also an odd emphasis on irrelevant issues like adherence to the schedule, even though calls and special projects make it difficult or inconvenient to take breaks at the exact time they are scheduled.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Lower the emphasis on adherence and "Hot Topics" because they are irrelevant to the job. Figure out a way to calculate "Actual Work Done" because there are many employees who get good stats but are doing only the easiest possible tasks.

review.title: “Great people to work with.”
review.pros: Pros – The company is not afraid to try new things. Ideas on their merits, not their presenter. Almost everyone here is a good person to work with - i.e. we don't hire jerks.
review.cons: Cons – Sometimes the company is too slow to recognize that a person is a poor performer. We usually deal well with this, but if an employee becomes a "favorite child" of someone in senior management, it can take several notable failures before they are recognized as incompetent.Office space is getting tight, and is leading to compromises which impact productivity and satisfaction.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The company is sometimes too quick to change direction on a whim. We sometimes loose sight of strategic goals to pursue the latest "shiny new thing". Being willing to take a slightly longer term view would, I believe, not only make the company more successful, but also more satisfying to work for.

review.title: “Do not read this review.”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock is good at hiring smart, motivated people and does not drag its feet when it needs to let someone go who is not cutting it. They do a good job of rewarding performance and are very reasonable about managing work/life balance. There is a lot of room for innovation and learning.
review.cons: Cons – As mentioned above, you can easily be let go if you don't do a good job. I think this is a positive thing, but some people probably wouldn't like it.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Be more clear about how the bonus pool is determined. It seemed that the formula that was established a few years ago (10% of nectar improvement) was abandoned, but nothing was ever said to employees. In my experience, bonuses have been generous, but it can still be frustrating to not know what to expect.A more consistent vision would also be encouraging. It seems like every year we're told, "Don't worry about GMS growth -- watch nectar growth." Then at some point everyone panics because GMS is too low.

review.title: “At Home with the O!!!”
review.pros: Pros – This company cares more about people (e.g. their customers, their employees, the community, our country, even other countries or cultures) then any other company I have ever worked for. They embrace all types of people and encourage diversity. Even with such a veriety of people working here, everyone still gets along and is happy to come to work everyday. They empower their employees to do what they feel is right for the customer and the company instead of setting ridgid rules. I have worked here for just over a year and already this is home. I love my job!
review.cons: Cons – As with any customer service job it can be difficult or trying to handle at times, however, less so here then any other customer service job I have had.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I would love it if we can work on getting more product information on hand to better serve the customers. We also have a lot of customers that will ask us what is the best item for their needs, it would be nice to have some training classes devoted to teaching people about variations in product lines (e.g. ceramic vs forced air space heaters) .

review.title: “Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – Great people, everybody is down to earth, great benefits, excellent opportunities for advancement, great atmosphere, good pay.
review.cons: Cons – Processes change a lot and sometimes we will get a call about the issue before we are notified of the updated information from the company. Have to work weekends (not a big deal at all but would prefer for us to be closed every weekend :) )
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – More thorough training for the new employees. Relay new updates to company before they take place. Put everybody through training again once a year to refresh our mind. Employees should be offered promotions based on the quality of the work they currently do. We should not be judged on who we know and how good of a recomendation a supervisor gives us. It seems as though there is a lot of favoring for people who are more popular. Which is very shocking considering how good all of the other aspects of this company are. I know people who moved up very quickly and only did a fair job in their previous position before the promotion (coincidentally they are very popular here). I always got praised on how excellent my work was, yet it was quite a fight to move up. Other leads do a not so good job and still hold their position somehow.

review.title: “Overstock.com knows that success is achieved through the empowerment of every employee.”
review.pros: Pros – The company understands that the customer is due respect and fairness when engaging in business. They are very receptive to new ideas regardless of the source. The only thing standing between an employee and success is effort.
review.cons: Cons – Sometimes the public view of the company is distorted by undeserved bad press.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Listen to the customer, it's their store.

review.title: “Overstock.com- 5 star review”

review.cons: Cons – Large work load. Could be better staffed
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Increase staff levels to accomodate work load. Some departments are overwhelmed while others are not.

review.title: “Love my job”

review.cons: Cons – I dont think that the pay is equal for the job descriptions.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Look at the way the pay is done. It would be nice to have everyone on an equal pay scale for the job they are doing.

review.title: “I love working at Overstock.com!”
review.pros: Pros – I think overstock.com has a great working environment. The culture allows us to be comfortable, but productive and I think that is incredibly important.
review.cons: Cons – I think Utah in general is low paying, and Overstock.com definitely fits that description.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – In my last position (within Overstock) I had a lot of interaction with upper management and I was very impressed with how approachable everyone was. I have now moved to a different department and I hardly ever have words with any of them. I wish that more people knew what a great executive team we have, and I wish they were more available for people who do not interact with them on a daily basis.

review.title: “Loves OSTK!”
review.pros: Pros – The majority of the management treats people as individuals and with respect. There are few places to work these days where there is a feeling of real community. I'm very glad to work here.
review.cons: Cons – A few bad apples - but there are those everywhere.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Provide positive feedback at least as often as negative feedback. You draw more flies with honey than with vinegar.

review.title: “Overstock.com from an employee's point of view.”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com cares about it's employees and really takes the employee's life and situation into consideration. They don't treat their employees like they are disposable and they are constantly reminding you how much value you are to the company.
review.cons: Cons – Sometimes I feel like my management plays favorites and isn't as understanding as they should be with some statistics. In my case, sometimes it feels like they are looking for quantity over quality.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I would like to see more consideration and understanding from leads on stats, just because some numbers aren't as high as other peoples doesn't mean that we are not doing more for the company that is not shown in those numbers.

review.employee-type: CS for Jewelry and Watches (Current Employee)
review.title: “Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – It is a great environment to work in very laid back, but people understand their job and do it well. Great people to work with.
review.cons: Cons – We do not get raises unless we want to be promoted, but I have been doing a good job on the same team for almost 2 and a half years but no raises except from tier tests.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Stop playing favorites

review.title: “The best company I ever worked for”
review.pros: Pros – The Company tries very hard to insure that everyone feels like part of the OVerstock.com family. they try very hard to make idividual workers feel empowered to get there job done and insure that the best result for the company and the customer. They also have an award winning team in customer service that they show quite a bit of praise for on a regular basis.
review.cons: Cons – there are some occasional situations where people may get favored over others because of who they know well or who they are related to. for as good at intercompany comunication it could be even better with the right systems in place.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep on doing such a good job. any complaints I have will probably be fixed on there own with out me even filling this out or are to be expected in any company

review.title: “I am proud to work at Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – 1. Overstock.com leaders do what they think is right regardless of what others might say.2. Overstock.com corporate values match my own: do the right thing; be respectful to customers, associates and others; take care of those who need it to the extent you are able; take care of the environment.3. You get measured based on what you contribute.
review.cons: Cons – 1. Overstock.com leaders do what they think is right regardless of what others might say.2. You get measured based on what you contribute.

Tell us what skills we need to advance, advise us on how we can acquire those skills, and build more programs to support. There are some, I am just saying we need more and they should be specific to each department.

review.title: “Great to work here”
review.pros: Pros – Great work environment. Supports learning, education, and interest in community and family.
review.cons: Cons – Pay and bonuses are unequal between different stores even though workload is similar.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Need a more clear and extended goal for each department and stick to it!

review.title: “Great department GREAT company I love how respected I am and I LOVE to shop here too!!”
review.pros: Pros – I love the hours I work and i love my pay rate. I love not working the weekends. I really love this job it's the BEST job I've ever had!! I always brag about how much I love my job cause I really do :) I love coming to work every day it's great when you have a job you truly love to do!
review.cons: Cons – My supervisor is great but she micro manages alot and that can be annoying. But she's great other than that, and I REALLY do love working here!
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Great management happy with overall performance!!

review.title: “Overstock.com is a great place to work.”
review.pros: Pros – Open, very even handed communication between staff and management. Personal issues are considered in every aspect: no rules are unbendable, but the fact that an employee is a person with a real life is always factored in.
review.cons: Cons – There is a certain amount of high schoolish popularity contest that seems to go along with the youth of this company. Advancements and opportunities seem to be reliant as much on how fun and personable someone is as much as how much actual effort they put into doing a job well. Also, decisions are made about perks--activities and recreational items, by a small select group rather than a majority agreement.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Management would do well to pay attention to the little guy--the people who do the dirty work of the actual customer contact. It seems that all of the perks and praise are alloted in the trickle down method, and we just get to hear about rewards and advancement. The employee of the month should be someone who answers the phone, not one of the people who monitors and assesses that work.

review.title: “Glad to be here.”
review.pros: Pros – Overall, a healthy corporate culture.Good technology--no career stagnation here.Life-work balance.OSTK is a good corporate citizen.OSTK is not a sinking ship; there is hope for my future here.Good teamwork.Approachable management.Problems get solved quickly; roadblocks get removed.No entrenched institutional incompetence; bumbling bureaucrats are not a protected class.Agile development environment means we DELIVER; we get stuff done.OSTK treats its customers well--I'm proud to be a part of that.
review.cons: Cons – Though agile works well here, and I actively support it, there are disadvantages. The environment can get loud. Distractions and interruptions must be managed.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Actively distinguish between the hard-working vs. those just skating by. If you don't, it's a complete sham. And it undercuts your own ability to lead in the future. If you have a hard working committed team mate beside one who's just punching the clock so to speak, and you treat them as equals, that is shameful (and it's really demotivating).

review.title: “Overstock is the best company I've worked for”
review.pros: Pros – Great CultureFlexible when it comes to family time.Opportunity for advancement
review.cons: Cons – Sometimes things are run "by the seat of our pants" not always a clear direction of what is expected in some areas.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Please consider that health benefits are of utmost importance to most of us. Please do not reduce coverage and please consider extending benefits to partners/spouses in nontraditional relationships.

review.pros: Pros – Overstock is a very employee friendly company. Their benefits and salary are awesome. There is so muc opportunity for growth and career advancement. The benefits are very good as well.
review.cons: Cons – There are only a couple downfalls. It's very hard to get your scheduled shift changed permanently. The flexibility of scheduling is a little sketchy at times.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I would say make scheduling just a little more flexible.

review.title: “A different company to work for--in a good way!”
review.pros: Pros – Work/Life balance is good. Management treats employees as resources. They generally weed out the back-stabbing jerks that many companies promote. There is a good sense of "we're all in this together" that I find refreshing. Overall, it is a professional environment that rewards you for your contribution to the team.
review.cons: Cons – Due to the quickly changing nature of retail sales, projects are sometimes delayed or discarded because a higher-priority request displaces it. I understand that some marketing aspects need to be confidential, but a little more visibility into some of the plans would be nice to know.

review.pros: Pros – Various training opportunities. Very nice people and a strong working environment. Upper management is understanding and is great to work with. Work load is challenging but rewarding. Always something new to figure out and many career building opportunities.
review.cons: Cons – The pay is lower than expected.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Upper management is very understanding and encouraging.

review.title: “OSTK is a great place to work.”
review.pros: Pros – The employees are hard working and good people. Management rewards employees based on merit. I like working with my colleagues.
review.cons: Cons – The company should focus on growing the business as much as it can, while making sure that it is profitable.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Continue to hold stand-ups to provide information to the company. Consider holding them in smaller groups to encourage more questions.

review.title: “This is a good place to work.”
review.pros: Pros – fair pay, good co-workers and things make sense.
review.cons: Cons – well, the only thing I could say is that in my first few months my training was more "jump in a lake" to learn how to swim rather than having someone teaching me how to swim...but that isn't all bad.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – keep up the good work

review.title: “Overstock.com, a great place to work at.”
review.pros: Pros – I personally have been in many other jobs in the past and I did not think that I would enjoy it here as much as I do. The family that we have here at Overstock.com is incredible. There are so many people and everybody has different views. The diversity here is awesome, and most everybody cares about our family here and also the customers. I couldn't think of a place that I'm prouder to work at than Overstock.com.
review.cons: Cons – The only problem that I have ever had with working at Overstock.com is the difference between shifts. It seems like there is always a fight between the people who work the daytime shift and the people who work the nighttime shift. I'm sure that situations like this happen at other places as well, but the amount of favoritism shown to certain shifts is a bit disheartening. Regardless, of all the gripes that one could have about a company, this is a small one.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Please realize that regardless of what shift a representative works, we are all great employees. Please try nto to show favoritism to the daytime shift. It is hard enough to try and motivate nighttime employees.

review.title: “Customer Service Representative”
review.pros: Pros – Very good atmosphere to work inVery diverse as far as the people that are hired.The people that are hired at corp, warehouse and in Customer Service have to be the greatest bunch of people I have ever known.Patrick Byrne is an amazing person and very interesting to learn about. I also like the fact that he is not just a name, he wanders around and meets people, and he remembers who he meets. I will work at Overstock hopefully for years and years to come. It is AMAZING.... I wish the pay was a little better, but to be honest, I would work here for less.
review.cons: Cons – The long hours during Q4... thats the only Con I can think of, but... they are well worth it.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the good work! you are AWESOME!

review.title: “Wonderful, friendly work environment”
review.pros: Pros – I have been working at Overstock.com for a little over two months, and I have been very impressed with the work environment. In other workplaces, I've struggled with employees who had power struggles and felt they needed to boss me around and belittle me because I wasn't in a position of authority like they were.The opposite is true at Overstock.com. I feel comfortable talking to executives like they were my best friends, and I have never felt that they didn't respect me because I was brand-new. The CEO and all of the vice presidents and other executives of the company are humble, friendly and completely open with their praise and occasional criticism. Their positive attitudes have in turn helped me to become a more productive employee, and I look forward to coming to work each day in an environment where no one is made to feel inferior to anyone else.I also value the teamwork that I feel at Overstock.com. Each one of the departments in the company works with others to make sure that everything goes smoothly, and each department is valued equally. I am impressed that everyone gets along and is simply trying to improve the company's performance. Even with good-natured competitions such as food drives and raffles between buildings and departments, the employees at Overstock.com work together and never put each other down, and that is something I value highly.
review.cons: Cons – The only cons I can think of while working at Overstock.com are that I sometimes feel like I don't have much to do in my position. However, this is not a fault of the company's but is a fault of the changing online industry that requires different techniques and tactics all the time. Once I have settled into a routine here at the company, I'm sure I will feel more fulfilled as an employee.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I am very impressed with how you and your executives have run this company and how dedicated you are to honest business practices. I am always proud to tell friends and acquaintances that I work at Overstock.com, because I feel that it is rewarding to work for a company that is dedicated to making life easier for millions of people across the world. There are no hidden fees, no ploys to get people to buy poorly-made merchandise to get it off our hands. You are a bunch of hard-working, ethical people who want to save everyone money -- and you're doing a great job. I'm excited to be a part of the team!

review.title: “Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – Friendly progressive environment. Professional but still allows people to be individuals. Most people on first name basis with all in their departments and many in the company.
review.cons: Cons – Workload is often overwhelming. Structure of who is responsible for what is sometimes unclear between departments.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I can't speak for other positions but PAMs are required to be experts in too many fields. Partner Billing, Fulfillment and CS issues on top of product knowledge and general merchandising can be a lot to keep up on. Increasing the size of teams like Partner Accounts Payable so they can take the lead on more issues would be extremely helpful so we could focus on merchadising.

review.title: “Overstock.com and Mr. Byrne alive and well heading into 2010.”
review.pros: Pros – Sharing of job knowledge within the company is the best of anywhere I've ever worked. I've been in the workforce for over thirty years and have never worked for a better company.
review.cons: Cons – Sometimes rolling out new projects or systems close to 4th quarter leaves employees a little frazzled. But we have all survived in one piece.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the good work!

review.title: “Overall satisfied”
review.pros: Pros – They are very understanding of family issues for example, I have worked at the Big O for year now and have had a couple of Family Emergencies and my supervisors were always very supportive.
review.cons: Cons – REQUIRED WEEKENDS FOR CUSTOMER SERVICE- You know Customer Service agents have a family too, and its nice that we can leave early on the day before the holiday, but if it falls before the weekend it would be nice to be given those days off, so we can have the long weekend like the supervisors do or UPPER MANAGEMENT to take a holiday vacation. If we have to come in to work the weekend to work and the holiday was a Friday or Thursday, it kind of ruins our Holiday Plans.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Most supervisors are so awesome! no complaints except for one but at least I only see her once every blue moon.

review.title: “Opportunities for Career Growth and Gaining Industry Knowledge Quickly”
review.pros: Pros – challenging, rewarding, difference making, laid back, fun, attitude from senior management down shapes the entire company. A great challenge while also a great culture.
review.cons: Cons – Much work to do in each position. You may be expected to work long hours. Career paths not well defined although getting better.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Great job from senior management. Most have been in lower positions within the company and it helps them relate. Make sure to keep your eye on the prize and make decisions accordingly.

review.title: “Overstock Review”
review.pros: Pros – A positive enviroment, a great potential for career growth, fair compensation, a diversity of projects which keeps the job interesting.
review.cons: Cons – There needs to be a better deal on overstock products for employees. There needs to be better communication about changes within the company.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – There needs to be better communication about significant changes within the company. Executives and upper management need to better respect others' time with respect to meetings. Cancelling, rescheduling, and not attending meetings on a regular basis is very frustrating when their input is needed to complete a task.

review.title: “It's all about the O! Or is it about the stock? I forget....”
review.pros: Pros – People are friendly. I get 2 screens. Bucky Flowers loves turtles. People are very understanding if you need to take acouple hours off for personal reasons. So far overstock is one of the best places I have worked.
review.cons: Cons – They dont feed you, or have a lunch room that serves food and drinks. Wish we got a better discount then what the public gets.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep working hard!

review.title: “Greatest Company I've Ever Worked For”
review.pros: Pros – Amazing support from managementMost companies like to hire from within but Overstock.com does this with overwhelming support and careGreat benefitsGreat Culture!Hard work is rewarded
review.cons: Cons – The only thing that I could really say is a downside is the compensation level. While it's still good and money is not my prime motivator. I feel that the work I do is worth a lot more than what I am paid.I've had some bad experiences with some members of managment. I sometimes feel that I get mixed messages from different members of my management staff.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Please give more feedback. I want to know how I'm doing. Also, take the time to hear what we have to say. Sometimes it feels that any interactions we may have with management, is not a collaborative one.

review.title: “Good Job”
review.pros: Pros – Good benefits, great pay, great incentives, Customer care week, Overstock.com takes care of their employees. Fairness, I feel like a family working with Overstock.com.
review.cons: Cons – Like every job there are a lot of personalities, so of course you're going to butt heads with people. Other than that it's really a good job. Can't complain at all.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – No advice, upper management is doing a good job.

review.title: “Overstock.com, Inc.”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com is a leader of online retailing, so employees can be sure they are up-to-date on trends and technology. The work atmosphere is dynamic and innovative, never stagnant and dull.The company has a diverse workforce for the region and a progressive attitude.
