review.cons: Cons – Wages are low for the industry in many positions. There is a lot of nepotism; managers tend to hire friends and siblings. People who are used to big-city lifestyles may find Salt Lake City a bit lacking in entertainment options.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Offer employees a way of reviewing managers, perhaps a form that requires meaningful feedback.

review.title: “Not a Bad Place at All”
review.pros: Pros – Pretty good at developing me professionally.
review.cons: Cons – Not the best place for pay, but that it is made up with the amount of knowledge I have gained working here.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep us going in the direction we are.

review.title: “Flexible young and dynamic”
review.pros: Pros – Great chance for advancement. Open to ideas and inovation. Empowers entreprunuerial thinkers. Performance bonuses give serious rewards to those who excel.
review.cons: Cons – salaries are good at the management level but poor for most new employees. They bonus heavily but it takes allot of faith for a new employee to invest a year with the hope that a bonus might help out later.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – some senior executives are good at recognizing good ideas and prioritizing them but others embrace all ideas causing paralysis. The company is also a little to siloed leading to suboptimal allocation of resources.

review.title: “Environment”
review.pros: Pros – It's a fun and open environment. It's good to have interactions with senior management on a daily/weekly basis. There is an environment of innovation and constant change.
review.cons: Cons – While the open environment encourages communication, it decreases efficiency and sometimes can cause miscommunication. Sometimes it can be noisy and difficult to concentrate.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – One of the best things that my manager ever did was to instigate monthly one-on-ones. It has helped me know where I stand as part of the team.

review.title: “For the most part, Overstock.com is a great company to work for.... good benefits, pay, etc...”
review.pros: Pros – Stable company who provides me the opportunity to earn a living while going to school.
review.cons: Cons – Not having the opportunity to take Sunday's off to worship in Church and spend time with my family when I am willing and able to work all day everyday throughout the week.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Find a better strategy of taking Sunday's off or trading system...

review.title: “Overall, excellent company to work for.”
review.pros: Pros – Very liberal work enviroment with freedom to make decisions. A lot of learning opportunities. Positive work enviroment with great morale, a lot of influencial dynamic people to work with. Challenging, yet rewarding job responsibilities. Executives and upper level management are fair and conduct themselves in an exemplary manner. They are personable and are great to work for. Compensation and bonuses are great. Benefits and 401K are also great.
review.cons: Cons – Advancement opportunities are hard to come by in this company. Occasionally, there can be a lack of communication and support from direct managers. Lacking a formal training class and cirriculum for new hires as it relates to the individual jobs. Time off days for new hires less than 2 years should be a day or two more than what is currently offered.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Overall an excellent company to work for. It may help some people thrive a bit more to offer performance incentives occasionally. It may also help new employees to the company to have one or two more paid time off days per year until they reach thier two year mark.

review.title: “Overstock.com Review”
review.pros: Pros – I love that there is potential to grow within the company. It is a very freindly company and all of the employees seem to really enjoy their jobs. You can tell that the company really cares about every employee
review.cons: Cons – It would be nice to have more cross training within the company.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Great job at noticing potential and a job well done. We notice how hard you work and appriciate it when you notice how hard we work as well.

review.title: “Great IT Staff”
review.pros: Pros – - Company is careful to hire the right people, and everyone works hard.- IT Department is very progressive and results oriented.- Best IT staff in Utah - Brainpower, good communicators, and few big egos.- Fun company events (Lagoon, Saltair concerts).- Office location is great (Old Mill).- Recently we got covered parking for all, a big improvement.- Good Compensation (Salary, Bonus, 401k).
review.cons: Cons – - Not enough PTO- Health Benefits are Mediocre (Would prefer IHC-based coverage).- Patrick's antics and outspoken behavior have created a lot of enemies, and left many outsiders scratching their heads. How will this affect the company long term?
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – - We need more PTO to recruit and retain top talent- Keep pricing competitive, it's our lifeblood, we can't let it slip.- Thanks for creating such an amazing place to work, keep it up!

review.title: “Need to think about the future”
review.pros: Pros – Fast paced environment to work inGreat leadersEntrepreneurial environmentCulture is open to new ideas
review.cons: Cons – Inwardly focus rather than focused on customer needsLimited benchmarking with competitors and deriving points of differentiationNew ideas not completely vetted and thought through before launching
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Need to develop long term, sustainable market position.Need to map a long term strategy on how the company will grow, what markets, what customer sets.

review.title: “Overstock”
review.pros: Pros – Very good place to work. Good equipment. Very good 'Help desk' people.
review.cons: Cons – WE are moving around very frequently.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – More information about strategy of the company. Short term goals, long term, etc...

review.title: “Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com has a very diverse group of employees which helps make it a very interesting place to work and provides multiple opportunities for professional and personal growth. The senior managemant of the company seems to place employee attitudes and desires at the top of their priority list.
review.cons: Cons – There are some unfortunate situations where there are employees that are protected by a few managers due to personal relations that tend to create a double standard in certain situations.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The hands on approach of management is fantastic, they seem to practice the Management By Walking Around model extremly well and always appear sincere when interacting with employees.

review.title: “Great company to work for. Have fun working here and enjoy the day.”
review.pros: Pros – Great Environment to work in. Great co-workers. Benefits package is good though from what has been mentioned before it is going to get worse.
review.cons: Cons – Pay is not comparable to same field in other industries.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Give workers the credit they deserve.

review.title: “Great Company.”
review.pros: Pros – The people. Hands down this company employs the best people. They are understanding about personal issues and always willing to go above and beyond for their customers AND their employees. They go out of their way to show their employees that they are valued.
review.cons: Cons – For the work that I do, I could be making a lot more money somewhere else. I feel that in my position I should be making more money than I am.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – My only feedback is to evaluate the salaries of every field and make sure you are paying your employees appropriately.

review.title: “Great place to work”
review.pros: Pros – It is a great place to learn new things and ensures that we are on top of all the industry changes
review.cons: Cons – club o discount is 5% which i believe covers the state tax. my friends get better coupons than I do to shop at overstock.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – keep up the fight against naked short selling. I am not sure if we will ever win the case, but I guess we should try hard before we give up.

review.title: “Wonderful open company to work for”
review.pros: Pros – Some of the Overstock.com pros would be:Great health benefitsGreat company attitude towards it's employeesSense of communitySo much knowledgeA level of freedom you never get at other companiesOverstock.com is very open to different ideas or perspective and often includes employees opinions or ideas.
review.cons: Cons – Some of the cons I have found working at Overstock.com are:Sometimes the company will pay you less than you are worth comparative to other companiesConstant moving of departments around the building
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I think that the managers need to continue to take an interest of the employees opinions just as they have been doing

review.title: “I love working here”
review.pros: Pros – Great people, fun environment. You get to do what you love and you are given the freedom to express yourself.
review.cons: Cons – The compensation is a bit lacking for the work and time you have to put in. Especially when you are salary, you are asked to give up your family time to help the company succeed. Many times, you make as much as a fast food worker when you divide the hours you put in by what you are paid.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – There should be pay grades like there are with the state. That way, everyone is fair and certain people that do the same job, but for a different area don't make more money for less work.

review.title: “Overstock is a good place to work”
review.pros: Pros – Lots of additional training . Opportunities to learn about new technology. Decent tools to do your job. My direct management understands my work.
review.cons: Cons – Growing too fast. Not a directed enough promotion or career path. Lots of stuff falls through the cracks especially after the "core" responsibilities are taken care of. Developers are somewhat separated from the nuts a bolts (both good and bad)
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – More directed career paths. Develop a wider technology focus or if that is already wide publicize it more. Keep up the good work.

review.title: “OSTK”
review.pros: Pros – Friendly staff, laid back environment, my buyer is fantastic to work for.
review.cons: Cons – Pay could definitely be better, communication could be improved.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I believe as a group we are headed in the right direction however there are a few things I am dissapointed with. Far less compensation due to the economic meltdown however we have added a lot more new positions then I can ever remember doing in past years. I also believe there are some people in crucial positions that definitely are not right for the job.

review.title: “Thoughts from the cubicle.”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com's wages are great comparitively and the work environment is far more pleasant than other call centers. The phone system is very efficient as well as easy to use.
review.cons: Cons – I am not satisfied with the growth opportunities available to me. I have applied for many different positions in many different departments, and have been passed on all of them, rarely even getting interviewed. My performance reviews are all positive, showing me as exceeding expectations, yet I am stuck where I am.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Compare call volumes from strategic days of the previous year before making decisions regarding changes to schedule and allocation of workforce on said strategic days.

review.title: “I like OS”
review.pros: Pros – Work/ Life BalancePromotions withinatonomyIntra-deaprtment communications
review.cons: Cons – Lack of manager training for those moving into new rolesYoung staff that has unrealistic demandsLack of overall ownership of the business by folks in certain rolesOverall unprofessional attire allowed at the company
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Create better training programs that are required to move up in the companyCreat consistentcy across all department of expected requirments (jobs, attire, attitudes, company goals, etc)Consistant praise applied for all areas of the business rather than certain areas be highlighted in large format meetings.

review.title: “A perfect job for the overly social and painfully personable”
review.pros: Pros – They have a relaxed and understanding environment, friendly coworkers, and can be flexible if you have scheduling needs. They empower you to actually help most customers without having to transfer all over the facility. plus it just feels good to hear a customer go from livid to grateful because you can do something for them.
review.cons: Cons – It can very stressful when you come across issues that you cannot solve yourself or that will take a long time to notate and deal with properly. There is a lot of abuse that customers throw at you from time to time and there are times when the frequency of calls can get to you.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I think we should move toward doing our own shipping instead of going through carriers as it would greatly empower customer service agents to deal with shipping issues.

review.title: “Generally Satisfied”
review.pros: Pros – The best part of working here is that there is a very friendly atmosphere. I like most of the people I work with, and my immediate supervisors have always been good people. The benefits are pretty good, not as good as they used to be, but still not bad.
review.cons: Cons – I know that most people who do what I do get paid quite a bit more, but I hang on thinking that one day I'll get paid what I'm worth. I've had a hard time trying to prove that not anyone can do what I do as well as I do, and management often sends the message that we can easily be replaced, even if they don't intend to.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I've seen a few people who do a lot less work than I do get promoted just because they are willing to suck up to management, and I think that's a little insulting to those of use who work hard but don't have that kind of personality. My advice would be to recognize that people who are quietly doing their jobs are still doing great -- and possibly better -- work.

review.title: “My Advice”
review.pros: Pros – The diversity of the employees is fantastic. I am impowered to solve customer concerns.
review.cons: Cons – There are no performance raises, so I am forced to change jobs in order to get a pay raise. The manager is unable to do any follow up, if you send her an email in never seems to be address. The management is so far removed for what I do they are unable to sympathize with my daily obstacles and they request task performed that slow down our process rather than aid us the completion of said task.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Feel that they assistant manager is better qualified to run the call center. He better understands the day to day trials that the agents gp through.

review.employee-type: Customer Service Representative S E A L (Current Employee)
review.title: “The Best Place To Work (EVER!!)”
review.pros: Pros – I have been here since 10/09/2009 and have already moved up, hopefully will continue too! Love the people and it is such a great job! We stay busy but all the while have fun!
review.cons: Cons – The 24/7 chat team just seems to ruin everything, they cause more problems then they solve.I'm tempt and don't know if I'll be perminate.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Let me keep my job!

review.title: “At work with The O”
review.pros: Pros – Most of the managers i have encountered have encouraged growth within the company by sharing their knowlegde and helping their employees succeed in the tasks they have given. Overall there are very positive people in management positions who are open and helpful to the associates they are in charge of.
review.cons: Cons – In my departmental transfers i have had difficult transitional periods adjusting to a head-strong individual who possesses an aggressive micro-management style but lacks the overarching grasp of his possition to assign tasks that have clear conditions in which the goals were to be achieved. Luckily, my flexibility allows a sort of middle ground where i get my job done without affecting anything adversely.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Most of the managers here show a willingness to get "into the trenches" and work alongside their associates shouldering the load when days get hectic, it's very comendable to see that motivation of "do as i do", rather than managing from a chair relying solely on delegation of leg work to leads to pass information up and down the chain. And it's not just middle management, the upper echelon of leadership is not afraid to get out on the floor and work up a sweat.

review.title: “Good company with a good heart.”
review.pros: Pros – They have lots of fun activites and competetions to keep people motivated. They are flexible when personal situations arise. I have heard of executives doing everything from paying someone's rent in an emergency to covering the cost of a funeral for an employee. They have employee only scholarships and things of that nature.
review.cons: Cons – The only complaint I have is that I got discipliary action based on a complaint from a coworker that was unsubtantiated.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Look a little further into issues before doing discipline. Other than that I enjoy the job and think we have a great company.

review.title: “Great Place to Work”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com is very supportive of their employees moving up in the company. They offer learning courses, provide opportunity to increase skill levels to help the employee reach their goals. Management works hard at making Overstock.com a fun place to work. Our CEO, Patrick, does not come across as too good to associate with the employees, he is very approachable and is open to the opinions of the employees. Senior management and management are always striving to show their appreciation to Customer Service for all the work they do.
review.cons: Cons – If I had to choose one thing that is a downside of Overstock.com it would be that the training is somewhat lacking.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – That training of new hires, be more comprehensive. The training given to the new hires, does not touch on International customers. This causes mistakes and more work for the agents who work with the international cusotmers.

review.title: “Great Company”
review.pros: Pros – Although the company is still considered fairly new the management staff of Overstock.com works very hard to insure that their employees are happy. We are a very diverse company which tends to work well for us and we are like one big family.
review.cons: Cons – Because it is still such a new company things tend to change very frequently. Although I placed this in the Cons list I would say it is actually a Pro as well because they are constantly working to improve internal processes as well as external process to insure they not only have happy and productive employees but they also have happy customers who are the life blood of our business.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up all of the good work. Strive to be as fair as possible in this diverse workplace.

review.title: “Overall - great place to work with great management values”
review.pros: Pros – Great leader who cares about the workforce and is visible, online business is recognized by everyone, work/life balance value, beautiful location
review.cons: Cons – People are promoted before they are ready, cramped work environment/not enough space (moves occur too often and without reasonable notice)
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Stay at Old Mill location and focus on achieving sustainable profitability

review.title: “Overall Overstock.com is a nice place to work I feel satisfied about my job.”
review.pros: Pros – The benefits received from Overstock are really nice.
review.cons: Cons – Some people are power hungry and get away with it.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Do not put people who want power in positions of power

review.title: “I provide expedited resolution to customers with difficult situations.”
review.pros: Pros – I was hired on in October and found myself promoted within 3 weeks. I love that this company only promotes from within. There is no need to worry that someone who does not understand the company will be moved into a supervisory or corporate position. There is definite room for self improvement and growth for anyone coming on board with no previous call center experience. If you have more to bring to the table, you are regarded as a gem and treated with respect; recognized for what you have to offer. There is a sense of family with Overstock.com that I have never felt while working with another company.
review.cons: Cons – At this time, I can't think of any. I love the fact that there is not a lot of stress in regards to "accidental overtime". If you have an hour or two posted to your paycheck, you aren't reeemed for it. Also, I have worked previously in a call center environment. You are allowed to document the reasons why you were not following your schedule and the information is updated in the system. You are treated like an adult and are not faced with disciplinary action for things that are not in your realm of control.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the good work. I would recommend more training programs for agents that would like to cross train for other departments - i.e. A+ certification, Spainish as a second language, etc; Anything that would help to improve the quality of the wonderful agents that you already have on the floor. And I would recommend more synchronized dancing for the senior staff. That was fantastic.

review.title: “Nice place to work with great CEO.”
review.pros: Pros – Excellent location, recognized name, young employee base, and opportunities for growth.
review.cons: Cons – Pay compensation is low and often varies depending on who is the manager in charge. Wish some areas of the leadership chain were stronger.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Might be a good idea to give anonymous surveys from time to time to poll the staff about ideas. Would love to see a tuition reimbursement program set up for those wanting to pursue higher education.

review.title: “Ethics of Retail?”
review.pros: Pros – Good pay, really nice and understanding management. A cubicle with a window view. I can't stress how much better that made my job. Everyone trusts eachother in my department, which is huge as well. I never felt like my opinion didn't matter or was flat out wrong. The training was also incredibly thorough and well done so that I learned my job well instead of quickly.
review.cons: Cons – Overstock.com is a glorified outlet store. As much as we try to push Worldstock, it is still hard for me to be passionate about working here. As a company we add nothing to the world at large. Sure overstock.com provides jobs in Salt Lake, and some revenue to the area, but besides that we aren't valuable contributers to society. On the one hand I like the idea of cutting out the middle man (the retail store seems like an antiquated concept), but on the other, we are actively engaged in the process of hurting local businesses. How do we reconcile this? I would bet that the vast majority consider their jobs at overstock just that, jobs, and nothing more. If there is a way to change this then that would be the only way to get people to truly believe in Overstock.com
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep your war on wallstreet as separate as possible from the brand name of Overstock.com. This battle that is deepcapture directly hurts Overstock.com stock prices, and therefore hurts employees of overstock who have good faith enough to invest in the company. It seems that it is an obsession and at times boils down to not much more than name calling. Enlist other parties to fight this war for you, remove your name from the battles. If it's truly about the ethics of it all then you shouldn't be worried about the credit you will receive.

review.title: “Nice to work at Overstock.”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock is a great place to work and to feel like you make a difference in the work you do.
review.cons: Cons – Only thing that comes to mind is some people put into a lead position are not ready and could use some extra training & mentoring.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – For the newer leads to make a team a team, they need some help in how to manage people and not be the know it all, since they are a lead and need to help the team out, not just themselves.

review.title: “Salary/hourly ceilings”
review.pros: Pros – Internal promotion opprotunities, unlimited access to OUniveristy
review.cons: Cons – Pay freeze in any position, general politics that you find with any company.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Remove the pay ceiling for all departments. If someone is doing a good job, they should get paid for it and not hit a glass ceiling just because they like what they are doing and do not want to switch positions.

review.title: “The Best Job I've Ever Had”
review.pros: Pros – Dress code/trivial aspects of the work place are the last thing you are graded on. Worthiness is performance based.
review.cons: Cons – Certain positions have a salary cap, and raises are no longer given based off time w/ the company.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Our business casual additude is key to a happy productive work place, keep it up!

review.title: “Great place to work, overall”
review.pros: Pros – You can expect an honest working environment at Overstock.com. The first thing that they tell you when you're hired is "If you're caught in a lie, there goes your job." I've had a few difference managers, all of which have good support for family values, work ethic, and schedule flexibility. The pay is great, and the hiring process is rigorous enough that few (if any) slackers get hired.
review.cons: Cons – Although there are opportunities for advancement within the company, most of them are management positions. There are few opportunities to advance purely on a technology level, even though the IT department (software dev, operations, etc) is quite large. Unless you are in management, don't expect anyone in management to really listen to your ideas. Even if you've been with the company for years, the lack of advance in job title says a lot.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – To the VPs and Directors, have more one-on-ones with those on the bottom of your food chain. There are things your direct reports would never tell you.

review.title: “I love my job”
review.pros: Pros – diverse work area, stand behind you... good advancement. Wonderful people to work with,. Higher ups are always there to listen and they don't act like they are higher then you.
review.cons: Cons – My commute is long and that is about it.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep doing what you are doing.. Proud to work for Overstock.com and all of the manangers.

review.title: “IT Department”
review.pros: Pros – Successful Company - high upside
review.cons: Cons – Poor internal communication. Projects are poorly managed due to Project Managers not being given accountable resources leading to wasted time, bloated projects, and poor internal resource development.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Form temporary project teams that overlap functional teams and report to project managers in addition to functional managers. Project Managers then report directly to VP’s. Project team members (for support) are then allowed opportunities beyond the day to day and business people are able to learn how to communicate with IT people and IT people are able to see firsthand the importance of business functions.

review.title: “Fantastic Company - Phenomenal People”
review.pros: Pros – work/life balancecompensation is top notchemployee skill level is higher than average with many top talents in the industryManagement is knowledgeable and they make good decisions for what's best for the company as a whole and not just individual teams or departments.
review.cons: Cons – Sometimes I think that management sets a goal or specific criteria to meet and then all decisions are based on meeting that goal even if it isn't the best thing to do. They become paralyzed from doing anything that might interfere with the all mighty goal they have set and therefore make stupid decisions instead of making smart and calculated risks ignoring the benefits to be had.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep doing what your doing - its working!

review.title: “Working at Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – Very casual and comfortable atmosphere. Has a good benefits package. Reasonably good teaching environment supported by an internally developed on-line university, which is constantly improving.
review.cons: Cons – Almost no potential for career advancement. Poor leadership support from management. Management strongly embraces a "Don't make waves" environment. Essentially no opportunities to provide feedback for management (this is the first time) or internal support departments.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – We need more of a push for teamwork between departments. Our environment is too contentious right now, we need to work towards a more cohesive operation between departments and move away from the current "Pass the buck" and "Don't make waves" feeling that we have now. The more people feel comfortable in voicing their thoughts and ideas, the more good ideas will float to the top. Last but definitely not least, give credit where credit is due. There is a lot of favoritism that happens in all departments, but no one dares to say anything.

review.title: “A good place to start, not a place to stay”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock is very flexible in allowing each person to find the niche that fits them best. Once you are past your first year, you can easily move to another area of the company to try another job that interests you. For the most part, the middle management is talented, competent, and professional.
review.cons: Cons – Senior management are no where nearly as knowledgeable about e-commerce as they should be. They form cliques with select middle management and only promote their favorite people not based on talent or job performance but because they are social friends. These "social promotions" into middle management have ruined certain areas of the company since the individual promoted has no talent and isn't up to the job at hand. Constructive criticism is taken personally, so one doesn't question their marching orders from senior management for fear of losing one's job. Pay is inequitable and based on whether senior management likes you personally, not your job performance.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Senior management needs to do the following:1) Learn to take constructive criticism not as a personal attack but positive feedback.2) Get rid of the "everyone is expendable" attitude; it's disconcerting when you say you want more loyalty to the company yet treat the talented people who do all the work as expendable.3) Value your employees through more postitive work related feedback and pay what they are worth based on job performance, work experience, and educational background.4) Stop promoting your friends and promote whoever is best for the job.5) Establish an "Overstock Mentor" program to provide employees with a way to learn from those who have been at the company longer, help increase knowledge sharing and employee performance, and help diversify employees' skills.

review.title: “Great Place to Work”
review.pros: Pros – Flexible hours, the ability to work from home when sick or bad road conditions, great compensation and bonuses, paid training and certifications, cutting edge technology, longevity of employees, internal university for genernal business knowledge and skills.
review.cons: Cons – The paid vacation is on the low end (2-3 weeks) and no sick days (even though some employees can work from home). That's about the worst I can say after working here for several years.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Encourage more team building exercises, increase salaried vacation by a week, and allow us to work from home more often. (maybe once a week)

review.title: “Striving to be #1 in Customer Service”
review.pros: Pros – The environment is like no other. Everyone around you works toward you succeeding you reach whatever goals you have in mind. People are incredibly friendly and helpful.
review.cons: Cons – Only downside I can even think of is that it is no fun with all of the sweepstakes we have that we can not submit a entry.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep doing what you are currently doing. Giving praises when they are due. I appreciate it very much and only look toward exceeding future expectations.

review.employee-type: Customer Care Night Team Lead (Current Employee)
review.title: “N/A”
review.pros: Pros – The overall moral of Overstock.com makes it an enjoyable place to work. I have moved up extremely fast within this company, and have always felt valued.
review.cons: Cons – I feel as though end of the year bonuses should be based more on performance. If you are exceeding extremely well in your job, then you should be rewarded
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Not really anything. I have a good report with management

review.title: “Overstock.com---What's it really like?”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com has a somewhat laid-back work environment which makes for a good work atmosphere. They seem okay with taking time off when needed for personal reasons, as long as it's not done excessively. Compensation seems to be competitive for the industry.
review.cons: Cons – For a company who believes in the philosophy of 'saving paper clips', they sure like to throw money away on frivolous things, like moving entire departments around all the time, tearing down walls and rebuilding them in different configurations 'just because'. There is definitely an atmosphere of favoritism, and most definitely an atmosphere of 'blame someone else'. Go ahead and throw someone else to the wolves...don't bother to take responsibility for anything.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – You have many good people working for you who are willing to give their all---Don't lose them by continuing with the status quo. Treat everyone fairly. Encourage personal responsibility. Above all, listen to your people. They're the ones on the front lines.

review.title: “What I think about my employment at Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – The starting pay is higher than most call centers in the area, and you can test to get better pay for within the first year.Overstock.com has a decent bennefit package.
review.cons: Cons – No anual increase in pay even for cost of living.High school atmosphere with a lot of clique or circles.Nepotism as with most work enviroments.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I would advise the management to listen to employees better, and to attempt to end the whole clique or high school like atmosphere.

review.title: “Headline”
review.pros: Pros – Commitment of upper management to success, and that success includes everyone at the companyLeadership has strong convictionsSense of Family and belongingSafe in a recessionFamily needs are carefully cared for (time off, etc)OUniversity and training are available and budgetedSome areas have conferences or trade shows they either host or attendGood value for customers, with a solid site and distribution systemLength of company's existence
review.cons: Cons – no walls leads to a feeling of personal space/constant distractionOne employee's faults lead to another employee's resignation/removal/holding back on promotionsDifferent divisions battle for resources and timeToday's most important thing will be forgotten in 6 months
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Last minute spending on large projects hurts the company more than it helpsCompetency is rewarded with more work, incompetence with power and promotion (not always, but most times)New software seems to be purchased based on dinners, and favors offered by companies instead of a thorough technical review of future needs.A central defining voice as to what the goals of the company are in the next 10-15-20 years would help technical decisions to be more relevant.All of these areas are improving each year, but we still have a long way to go.

review.title: “Truth”
review.pros: Pros – A progressive company with a bright future.Honor to be a part of the brand 'Overstock'.
review.cons: Cons – Deep rooted politics that favors 'survival of the fittest'. By fittest I mean someone who can praise his supervisor for anything. Basically a "YES" man.Salary is extremely low for the work we do. Management says that bonus will compensate for the low salary, but my experiences are different.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – There are very few highly qualified executives in the senior management team. Hire some brains with experience and strong academic background, this will bring some poise; professionalism and elegance to the company culture.

review.title: “Working for Overstock.com has ups and downs”
review.pros: Pros – The diversity. Overstock.com welcomes people from all cultures to work here and its great to share in other cultures here at work.
review.cons: Cons – The favoritism. When there are openings for specialty teams they will not take on anyone that they are not friends with, even if we are qualified. Agents that are friends with the management get treated much better and they get more understanding about needed schedules. If the manager of Quality does not like you then your stats fail as well.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Look at why people might be unhappy. It might be some of the management themselves treating people unfairly. Patrick is a wonderful employer, I just dont think that he is aware of what happens in his call center

review.title: “As a job......it pays the Bills”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com pays their employees fairly well for starting out. They do provide their empolyees with two fifteen minute breaks and one thirty minute lunch.
review.cons: Cons – They do not pay their employees due to experience. I have been in the customer survice industry for the past nine years and make the same as a kid in high school that works at Overstock.com. Sicne I have been with Overstock.com I have slowly grown to wonder how they have been around for ten years. The company stress how important customer satisfaction is, yet management stress getting a certain amount of contacts, which leads employees to cut corners on doing their job. Rather than taking the time in reading what is going on in a particular incident, employees will touch the incident enough to make a "contact out of it". If the economy was not in the shape that it is in and jobs where readily available, I would leave Overstock.com and go to where the work that I do can be appreciated.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Fix your system. Be willing to listen to someone new to the company. Just becasue the person has not been with the company that long does not mean that they are not able to help the company progress forward. If you have employees working overtime to assist with work load, let them know how much they are appreciated. Money is not everything. I have been with the company now for almost three months and for roughly the past month I have dreaded coming to work due to the fact the management is not focusing on quality. Instead they are focusing on numbers. Perhaps this is why Overstock.com was rated one of the worst companies to return items to according to either the today show or good morning america. Will this make a difference probablly not. I have personally gone to management about several things with no outcome. So I will leave it at that.

review.title: “Upset and dissatisfied at this time, used to be very very happy.”
review.pros: Pros – I love Patrick and Stormy and thier encouragement and just the spirit they bring to this place. I love the family thing they are trying to create but it wont happen with all the favortism in this place.
review.cons: Cons – I have been here for years and watched people pass me by time after time. I have managenent experience that they have never considered. I see trouble makers that should have been fired years ago be excused for thier actions time and again. The favortism is at an all time high in this place and seems like more and more people are unhappy and looking for optional jobs as they dont see a future here anymore. It is so frustrating to work hard for years and years with a perfect record with attendance, quality, you name it and then see new team leads that have just got hired and us (oldies) have to train them properly , because they are so new, but making more than you and you should have had thier job in the first place-NOT FAIR!!. You see people you work with for years change when they get power and unfortunatley not for the good. I hope that Stormy and Patrick figure out what is going on around here and fix it before too many of us are gone:(:(
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I dont know what to say. I just know to come in and keep my mouth shut cuz if I say the wrong thing I could be gone but Joe Blow who is one of the managers nieces or brother or such can have the worst attendance and attitude and tehy get promotions. I know that Patrick and Stormy do not see this as I beleive they would not allow this to be going on. I hope other people mention this so someone will look into it. I would sure like to stay with Ostock but I cant stay if things dont change. For the first time here I feel like I have no one I can trust and no one to go to with my issues. I was told NOT to go to Stormy about management or I would be canned. Please Patrick HELP US:(:(

review.title: “My review for Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – Fast paced environment, perks for performing the assigned job correctly, feeling like you are a part of something that has the potential to be huge.
review.cons: Cons – Wages are not competitive, a lot of departmental politics, finger pointing and backstabbing, seems like some individuals have difficulty in accepting the responsabilities that come with their titles, often feeling like there is the proverbial gun to your head, so bite your tongue and do not speak your mind when issues arise.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Watch department managers to be sure their department is what they are focused on, not keeping secrets or encouraging inner-departmental back-biting. Revised pay scale for employee retention and better quality of life.

review.title: “cons outweigh pros by far”
review.pros: Pros – The people in my department are great--we have a great support system and good work ethic. The benefits are okay. The bonuses (if any) are generous. Time off requests are usually granted. PTO accrual is reasonable.
review.cons: Cons – No opportunity to advance (I was told this in my interview); communication barriers with upper management; sometimes we (as a department) feel we are treated as incompetent people because we don't have freedom to complete our jobs the ways we see fit; ignored by management when offering suggestions for improvement; ignored when asked for explanation on low wages; very low wages (for people with degrees in the field); no trust with upper management; job doesn’t seem secure when it's not fourth quarter
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Listen to the people in the department--we are educated, competent individuals full of good ideas and we are not being utilized.

review.title: “Overstock.com does care”
review.pros: Pros – The pros about working at Overstock.com are you do have the opportunities to Advance in your career. Also the co-workers are all very helpful and great. And they do care about the customer.
review.cons: Cons – The cons in Overstock.com do not pay as well as other companies in the industry, no education benefits. Schedule changing within 24 hours of shift, working 99.00 hours in a pay period. Raises taking over 5 weeks after promotion.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Training to your employees on new M&P, communication with the company on changes. Meetings with teams at least once a month.

review.employee-type: With This Level of Honesty, I Don't Think So (Current Employee)
review.title: “Overall good place to work”
review.pros: Pros – There are some crazy smart people and just being around them rubs off. I am able to go to school and still pull my weight. There are cutting edge technologies and a high level of sophistication in the tools I use to do my job.I appreciate that we are being given an opportunity to comment. It shows a willingness to consider alternate points of view.Stand-up meetings are awesome. Interacting with management and getting a sense of the "vision" that they have for the company, makes us stand apart.I often hear complaints about being required to move from one desk to another and change floors. I actually think that this is a good thing and have met and got to know all kinds of people in various departments thanks to this simple strategy.
review.cons: Cons – Maybe it is the stress of the job, but occasionally angry, and unhelpful email messages make it down from the upper levels. My boss and my bosses boss often find themselves trying to comprehend a email message sent down from "on high" by someone that is completely out of touch with reality. I am in a position to have seen this from multiple departments and don't believe it is isolated to my department.There is a tendency to play the blame game. Occasional witch hunts result in a environment of fear. Often the first responder attempting to solve a critical issue gets summarily executed when the solution does not work.I am highly awarded from previous companies and receive regular positive feedback from my peers and those internal customers that I work for, but have a tinfoil hat feeling that I am being stopped in my progression due to misconceptions that persons above me have harbored for years.I suspect that promotion will happen after I leave school and leave the company. Several long conversations with my colleagues, suggests that I am not alone in that feeling.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – A position of leadership is a service position. Often a leadership position is not because you are smarter, but because we need someone to make a final decision.If a person sticks their neck out to help and gets whacked when the result is not positive, you are teaching that person to avoid sticking their neck out.The blame game results in a toxic environment within a team.

review.title: “Listen to your employees in the warehouse”
review.pros: Pros – Easy going attitude among managment
review.cons: Cons – tight security for the warehouse, and it is of questionable effectiveness, since stuff still goes missing. I have also wittenessed security gards hassel a worker for bringing his own box cutter.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – It is ok to talk about job functions with subordinates. They know their job better than you do, since they do it everyday. If you will pause to help them see the big picture, and listen for suggestions on improving things, productivity and moral will increase.

review.title: “The good, the bad, and the ugly”
review.pros: Pros – Working for Overstock has given me my first introduction into medium sized companies. I've worked for large and small, both growing and shrinking. This has been a good company to work for that has shown the stability of larger corporations, without the political bull.
review.cons: Cons – Management appears to be a good ol' boys club. If you want to advance your career, this is not really the place, as you have to be a member of the club to advance. There is no education assistance, meaning that I don't have a corporate support for learning.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Break up the good ol' boys club, and remember that the people who work for you are real people, too (car guys, etc). And, even though morals state that something is right, you can go overboard on it (extremes).

review.title: “Customer Service Job Experience with Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – The job itself is fairly simple and satisfying. You get the opportunity to help others, you have a lot of freedom to resolve customer issues in the way you see fit and fair to both the company and the customer. You are given plenty of training not only when you join the company but as well as ongoing training. They have many supportive opportunities such as health advancement with both healthy tips and recipes and community support. The people working for Overstock.com are friendly and diverse, you feel welcome and respected for who you are by your co-workers. There is room for advancement if you are interested and qualified. The benefits are great. Overall, the environment is wonderful as far as the atmosphere and the co-workers. The Customer Service community is fun, open, welcoming and warm.
review.cons: Cons – It is very difficult to get positive feedback and you will always be informed of areas you need to improve in. Though there are plenty of job advancements available, it is very difficult to get one of these positions without knowing the right people. There is very little flexibility as far as time off for personal reasons that you may feel are important. There is not a strong feeling of connection or or openness with management. There is no opinion or feedback sharing ability, complaints are frowned upon. It is made clear that if you do not meet all expectations for any reason that there are plenty of others to fill your position. There seems to be a large communication gap between the employees and management as you have nowhere to give feedback on improvements that can be made, complaints that you want to be left anonymously etc. Management does not seem to apply the "open door" policy that most companies do as offering opinions and complaints leave one a bit "flagged." As long as you just do your job and don't try to change or address anything, you will do well with this company. If you want to offer changes, improvements, share opinions and such, this is not the place for it. You are not given a voice without repercussions.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The management should be looked at closely as there seems to be a lot of nepotism, unfair treatment as far as who is picked for promotions or demotions. There is a very large amount of favoritism and many have watched under-qualified new agents take positions that others who were not only more qualified, but had also been with the company longer, had applied for. The person who knows someone in management or has made themselves known to management will get the position above the qualified agent. The "cliques" have grown stronger over time and those in them continue to promote and also continue to be protected against their poor behaviors where others find themselves with write-ups and repercussions. Most are not fond of the customer service management unfair treatment and also unhappy with the protection they offer others who are not following company policies or are even crossing behaviors that are HR worthy. If one wants to promote within customer service or even promote out of it, one must be on the good side of certain parties in customer service management or even if they are qualified and with a clean record, they will never promote and have even been demoted from specialty teams and such so others could stay on or promote who are in favor. Agents discuss and continually wish that the upper corporate management would take interest in the unfair practices and treatments going on at the Customer Service center, but there is no forum for them to get this information to upper management. There needs to be some sort of opinion and complaint forum, box or such for agents to submit this type of information to those above the management team over Customer Service so it can get to ears that have the authority to take interest in it. Most agents have given up and no longer take their issues to anyone and have learned to just stay quiet as previous attempts to have issues address have failed, gone unnoticed, been ignored or ended in retaliations. Management even presses upon agents that they should take all issues to them and NOT to HR as they want to resolve the issues and do not want issues to be taken to the HR level, even if this is where it should be addressed. They have even had HR representative in the past who bring all the issues to their attention even when agents do not want this to be the resolution as the reason they took it to HR is to avoid the ears of management. There are serious issues and many would appreciate it if some of these things were brought to light, addressed or at least investigated.

review.title: “I'm Fine with Most of It”
review.pros: Pros – I thoroughly enjoy the department I work with. My co-workers are the reason that I enjoy coming to work every day. I work in a very relaxed, yet professional atmosphere. This company offers excellent benefits and they work well with my schedule. I don't carry the job home with me, it's not that stressful, most of the time.
review.cons: Cons – While I like my department, I feel isolated and ostracized from the rest of the company. I don't feel like we're valued as employees or even people, at times. It also seems that the only time the higher-ups interact with us is when they criticize or make changes to our department. It seems many people use intimidation to make their employees subservient. I don't feel my opinions are valued or given any weight in the company. Sometimes I fear that offering my opinion at all will cost me my job.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Don't just tell your employees that they are valued - show them. Make sure to show respect to the opinions and feelings of even the lowest positions in the company. Get feedback from the departments that you are considering altering before you make the changes. Your employees have a lot to offer this company.

review.title: “Overstock.com call center”
review.pros: Pros – The pay is very good for customer service and the ability to actually move into different positions is an excellent way to never be bored at work. Many of the people here are very friendly.
review.cons: Cons – The locations of the company are very inconvenient and out of the way. Quite a few supervisors are condescending and don't treat people with respect. The call center is located within a warehouse that gets very loud when it rains or if there is a truck in the warehouse and the customers are very displeased with this when this happens. There are also times that supervisors will collect on the call floor and applaud while customer service representatives are on calls nearby. Sound travels very well and makes speaking with customers difficult. There is no covered area for smokers at the call center and does not help with morale.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Be more personable. If we are happy we are more likely to work hard for you. All you do is talk down to us and you will never get results this way. treat us like humans and we will make you look good.

review.title: “Review of first impression of OSTK.com”
review.pros: Pros – the diversity - but the appearance of some employees could be more professional - like one hair color - and pants pulled up on the waist - (no cracks please)
review.cons: Cons – Echocontact 3 is subpar - it doesn't allow you to tell how long you have been on a break - it duplicates ADP time mgt - in my opinion Aveya is a much better and time efficient phone system and WFM - appears to have way to much power, their responsibility is to oversee scheduling do control ones life - the system they use changes schedules constantly and arbitrarily without notice at time and expects people to change their schedules - putting in a system were you bid on a specific schedule and keep it for 3 months at a time without changing it would help alot - WFM forgets that life happens and they act and appear and have way to much power and have a horrible reputation - not to mention the emails we constantly get when we are in wrap up to long (according to WFM) its disruptive and really annoying when you are trying to help a customer - the call center is so far away from civilization - we need ice machines -
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – restructure WFM - leads need to take a more active roll with the people on their team - get rid of the name "seal (s)" - it connotates images of seals wallowing on the beach - there should be cubicles as there is really not much privacy here - when o.t. has been requested and calls holding why is escalations always short staffed? and why are the other departments closed on Sat.? this is a disservice to our customers who try to get ahold of them - tell are a few more issues that I have.

review.title: “Overstock can be #1”
review.pros: Pros – cutting edge technology. CEO is great.
review.cons: Cons – direction.. road map... not able to do much with the resources available.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – i'm not good at it, but let me start by saying Overstock can be #1...we need to have more leaders who can see beyond the horizon. leaders who dare speak their mind and not just say things that their boss would like to hear. tools are only good on how they are applied. too many developers not much direction.

review.title: “Overstock.com is a fantastic company to work for but very difficult to get a promotion without knowing the right people.”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com is a great place to work. There are always opportunities to learn new skills and gain new knowledge regarding the company’s business. The company’s corporate office is comfortable and well maintained. Its primary call center and warehouse are brand new facilities that are clean and also well kept. The CEO is something of a rogue and both inspires and motivates his people to challenge the establishment. The company has a strong interest in system engineering and system improvement which should go a long way in improving company profitability in the near future. Pay is good for those in the buying and technical departments, if you can land a position with them. Overall, it’s a good company to work for and a good place to learn the online retail business.
review.cons: Cons – The most frustrating part of working for Overstock.com is that it’s very difficult to move up in the company without knowing the right people or having the right contacts. While this is a reality in many companies, it seems to be even worse here. That’s not to say that they don’t give you the chance to learn the business…just that you’ll usually never have a chance to use what you’ve learned. Recommendations to improve operations are welcomed but it seems only by a select group and only through a very ridged chain of command that seems to kill those recommendations before the rise high enough to be evaluated. The hardest part for me is that I feel as though I’m learning a great deal only to have to go to another company if I ever want to have the chance to put that knowledge to use and advance my career.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The message from the top isn’t always reaching the lower levels of management. It’s not uncommon that we hear powerful and inspiring things from top leadership, only to have the message get lost when it gets to middle and lower management. I recommend opening up to suggestions from your grunts on the front line. You have some amazing and brilliant people working for you. In one specific department that comes to mind, you had enough talent to start a multimillion dollar start-up, and these brilliant individuals were repeatedly passed over for promotion for others with far less knowledge and talent. Overstock .com has the talent and human capital to truly crush the competition but in some areas it will need to get out of its own way to do it. The humble opinion of one of your loyal grunts.

review.title: “Clear strategy and vision”
review.pros: Pros – Casual work atmosphere. Friendly co-workers.
review.cons: Cons – Compensation is low comparing similar positions at other technology companies - even within the state of Utah.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Less focus on the fight with Wall Street and less unnecessary moving of departments, teams and work groups. More focus on the fundamentals that will help us achieve our financial goals. More clear strategy - who are the primary competitors we are taking on and what is our strategy to take market share from them.

review.title: “Overstock.com Review”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com is a great place to learn quickly about eCommerce. Most people who work here are easy to get along with. The health benefits are above and beyond what most other employers are willing to do.
review.cons: Cons – Many times it seems that the 'popular' people are promoted, or others who are just 'yes-men.' Also, experience within Overstock.com is not as valued as much as job experience else where. I understand that some projects need a fresh look, but when the new employee is hired with 40% more salary, and has the same skills and experience, that's insult. Especially when I have to train the new employee.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I suggest that Overstock.com works harder to keep their current employees through promotions and raises. Also, management needs to give employees a chance to take on new responsibilities and be given recognition for a job well done.

review.title: “Cons starting to outweigh the Pros?”
review.pros: Pros – My coworkers are some of the brightest people I've had the pleasure to work with. Their enthusiasm and commitment to excellence is inspiring.Overstock.com supports some great programs - Worldstock and the Wounded Warriors Program are causes I'm proud to be associated with.The company's (theoretical) ideals are ones I respect.Benefits are great.Patrick Byrne private events are fun!
review.cons: Cons – Compared to other companies in the area the wages for my job are especially low.Though I do a great job and take pride in my work I've received no feedback, positive or negative, on my performance.There are policies the company claims to have that are not followed. I don't trust that this survey will remain anonymous, for example.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Take a minute to check in with your employees - let them know you appreciate what they're doing. Show respect for a knowledgeable employee base - we know what we're doing and do it well.When you do ask for input at least pretend to consider it - or don't ask. Complete disregard for input is worse than not being consulted.

review.title: “It's....fine.”
review.pros: Pros – The benefits are very good. There's quite a bit of movement within the company, so if you're willing to slide into whatever position needs filling, you can work your way up the chain. The Cottonwood area is nice and the view of the mountains is lovely. The executives are accessable and, for the most part, down-to-earth.
review.cons: Cons – The pay is unremarkable, to say the least. Hourly employees might appreciate it if there were sick time that's separate from PTO. Seating arrangements are strangly close and offer little privacy. It feels like different areas of the company are strongly polarized in terms of how knowlegable and dedicated the employees are; some areas are excellent while other areas seem to be filled with people coasting through life. So if you want a challenging environment where standards are high and deep insights are valued, look elsewhere. I think Overstock.com would a good place to get ahead by being an attaboy or a personal friend of somebody, if that's your preferred method of career advancement.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I do hope that the higher-ups strive to bring excellence into ~all~ levels and areas of the company.

review.title: “Not a bad place to work”
review.pros: Pros – Some good people here.Seems to be a reasonably mature workplace, ie, no regular 60hour work weeks, people respected for the most part, etc.
review.cons: Cons – small amount of PTO, most tech companies are moving to 4 weeksPTO combined with sick time is a very obnoxious policyHealth plan just acceptable, could be much better.High level management sometimes random.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The policy of combining sick time with PTO encourages people to come to work when sick so they don't lose vacation time. Get rid of that policy.

review.title: “Good place to work. . . if you are okay with coasting.”
review.pros: Pros – Good benefits, flexible schedule and okay pay!
review.cons: Cons – Hard work does not get recognized. Leadership rolls are given to the ones that party and hang out with management. Year end appraisals have been determined by new management that has not had the chance to fully work with the employees to see their work, instead they go by what they hear.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Look to promote talent not just friends.

review.title: “Customer Service”
review.pros: Pros – There is a tradition to caryy and management attempts to get the tools you need to get the job done right.
review.cons: Cons – No sick pay. No yearly pay raises. Little room for advancement despite it being highly touted. Who you know is more important than your production level.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Customer Service has 3 leaders that often have 3 separate visions they need to get on the same page.

review.title: “Wasn't a great place to work”
review.pros: Pros – Great benefits, good entry level position before I went back to graduate school.
review.cons: Cons – No way to move up in the company, inexperienced SVP's.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Better pay means better workers.

review.title: “Overview of Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock provided a great work/life balance and offered many benefits. For the most part, they took care of their employees.
review.cons: Cons – Overstock.com could have done a better job at providing a career progression plan within the company.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Overstock needs to do a better job at focusing on its core competencies. Many times they bounce from idea to idea.

review.title: “Great place to work”
review.pros: Pros – It's great to work with really smart people in a fast-paced environment. There are plenty of great learning opportunities available and tons of interesting projects with which you can become involved. Employees are mostly very fun and motivated people. If you're smart and work hard there are lots of opportunities for upward movement within the organization. CEO is accessible and works closely with employees on a day-to-day basis. He gave me a very generous public compliment on my first day. :) Management is primarily numbers-driven with really clear expectations. Great benefits and lots of paid vacation time.
review.cons: Cons – Sometimes the org chart could become a little unclear. Not a big problem overall though.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the good work.

review.title: “I love Overstock.”
review.pros: Pros – Great career opportuntities to move and grow. I've been at overstock for six years and have enjoyed working with smart people who push me to move and grow in my career.
