review.title: “The non-compete is a problem. Outsourcing is ramping up.”
review.pros: Pros – Management finally responded to the many complaints about the horrible non-compete.
review.cons: Cons – The non-compete is still horrible and still severely limits future career opportunities. Overstock conveniently brings the non-compete up for the first time on the first day of work after you've uprooted your life, relocated, and turned down other job offers but before they give you access to walk through any doors by yourself. The same non-compete is used for both experienced employees in key roles and new hires fresh out of college.Since the new non-compete was not made available when it was announced, and the Senior Vice President - Technology / CTO took a determined stance to not make it available until either a position title change occurs or a new bonus is given, here's how the CTO phrased the non-compete changes. These are his exact words as best as I can remember. "We've had a lot of complaints about the non-compete and so sat down with our lawyers to update it. We decided the clause basically limiting employees from working for anyone with a website was overly broad since basically everyone has a website now." He continued "So we've changed that part to say anyone with a transactional website."The updated non-compete wording still limit's everything from a mom and pop shop which competes with Overstock because they sell t-shirts on the internet and so does Overstock, to Microsoft because Microsoft sells tablets on their website and so does Overstock. Don't forget Google because Google sells advertising space and Android phones on their website and so does Overstock. Combine that with Overstock's unpredictable business models which have ranged from selling vacation packages, to insurance, to cars, to homes, in addition to overstocked merchandise and the scope grows even more.Essentially if Overstock chooses to come after you, the non-compete wording forces you or your new employer to take the matter to court, in Utah, or quit your new employer and find another job. Overstock has done this in the past for relatively low level people. Over the last few years the non-compete has been frequently updated to restrict more and more future employment options and has become required for more and more people. The CTO's opinion that this latest update removed the overly broad scope and his determined stance to keep the exact new non-compete wording private until they want you to sign it on the spot scares me.As part of the same meeting it was announced that Overstock will work to outsource 15-20% of it's relatively small development and test staff of around 150. Luckily these will all be new hires, at least for now. The cover story is they want to be able to fire 15-20% of the development staff on a whim. The CTO cited a previous year this happened and basically said better outsourced workers than you.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Get serious about fixing the overly broad non-compete. Reserve non-competes for individuals that are critical to the organization's performance and have key confidential information instead of everyone. Don't try to retain people by surprising them with a draconian non-compete at the last minute as a condition of employment. Listen to people involved in the current positions or hiring process instead of just lawyers when drafting the non-compete. Let the lawyers earn their money and stop using a one size fits all non-compete. A CTO, an architect, and a new hire out of college have vastly different roles and vastly different access to confidential competitively advantageous information.

review.title: “IT a mixed bag”
review.pros: Pros – The work life balance is great and the pay is decent. Very few teams work more than 40 hours a week. Schedules are very flexible and the time of day you show up for work is basically left to your own discretion. If a project date is slipping almost always project features get cut or the date gets extended with overtime very rarely considered a recovery option. Recent changes are providing opportunity for advancement and existing employees are being considered first for those positions.
review.cons: Cons – Their non-compete agreement is ridiculous. Get a copy of it before you entertain an offer. Team leads are given the late night on call responsibilities. Nepotism and cronyism in the company is rampant. Despite management saying they hate politics, politics are prevalent, nurtured, and only growing in importance. A sideways look, a word thought to be disrespectful, or bringing up concerns about the group think strategy of the day are quite literally fireable offenses. Critical thinking and good project execution seem a distant second to getting along. Accountability appears to flow only one way. The practice of hiring from within and cronyism has led to several in positions of authority who from my perspective perform their responsibilities poorly and are unlikely to leave since neither their experience nor aimless performance is likely to qualify them for comparable position and pay in other companies.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Reign in the growing prevalence of politics and cliques. Encourage thoughtful discussion of opposing viewpoints. Reward excellence in execution and critical thinking rather than getting along and yes men / yes women. Nip the environment of intimidation and random firings in the bud. Have senior management exercise some basic management skill and discuss issues with people when there are issues instead of the first and only step, or preferred go-to action, being immediate termination or forced resignation. Update the 360 degree review process so it's less dangerous to leave constructive feedback that is critical of management. It is completely unsafe currently since managers choose who review them and know with certainty who wrote most or all of the 2-4 anonymous reviews they receive. Most of the shills that managers choose identify the review they wrote and simple process of elimination in the small pool of remaining potential reviewers presented to managers reliably identifies the others. This leaves the aftermath of retaliation and resentment just another enforcement of what appears to be the fall in line and never bring up flaws company ethos.

review.title: “Development Lead”
review.pros: Pros – Good technical environment, smart folks around you. Processes do not get in the way of getting work done.
review.cons: Cons – Development leads do not do much development, Title should really be Development Manager as an important responsibility is managing people. (think smart eccentric people).Marketing and Product Management teams suck.
review.advice-to-management: Yes, I would recommend this company to a friend – I'm optimistic about the outlook for this company

review.title: “Good people.”
review.pros: Pros – good and smart people to work with.
review.cons: Cons – pay less than the industry.

review.title: “Not enough opportunities for long-term employment (oh and too much capital wasted on lawsuits)”
review.pros: Pros – Executive Visibility - in the hallways and in meetings. Great opportunity to get to know them and what they want.Collaboration - open seating and open doors, opened many opportunities to work together.Family fun - Lagoon day is an employee favorite and special treat.
review.cons: Cons – Advancement opportunities are undefined, delayed and often dissolve into thin air without explanation.Positions descriptions were nebulous and subject to territorial executives' every whim and personal like/dislike.Leader promises (no - leader commitments) were more times than not a placebo to competitive weaknesses
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Perform more skip level type meetings or front line meetings to get a better sense of morale and engagement.

review.title: “Operations manager”
review.pros: Pros – Good coworkers, family friendly, and good working environment
review.cons: Cons – Lack incentives; some people need more projects to fill the working time

review.title: “Former Director”
review.pros: Pros – * The company is willing to take risks in the attempt to grow market share and profitability.* Employees are given opportunities to own and manage projects that impact the company's performance.* Innovation is encouraged and ideas are identified, extracted, and deployed.* Many bright, competent people have worked here creating a good platform for growth.
review.cons: Cons – * Not thorough: Many projects are only partially completed giving quick, short-term benefit - but will require additional time and expense to fix patches and untangle errant solutions to achieve long-term results.* Incompetence: Too many "Yes Men & Women" at the top (SVP's/VP's) always agreeing with Patrick (which works most of the time) - but most don't have the knowledge or experience in their fields to truly bring the company to the next level.* Very Political: SVP's/VP's often won't listen to ideas that aren't their own and will quickly take credit for successes where credit isn't due.* Strong Egos: Strong egos in upper management prohibit growth, improvement, and innovation. Threats, intimidation, and ego are present in almost every meeting attended by an SVP/VP.* Turnover/Loss of Talent: Many key contributors have either left because of lack of advancement opportunities, poor compensation, or complete dissatisfaction with upper management or have been told to leave when upper management feels threatened.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Read "Cons"Have a meeting to eliminate 1/2 of the non-critical meetings.Focus on results, but identify key contributors and reward them.Clean house (Upper Management)

review.title: “Great place to grow and learn”
review.pros: Pros – Great advancement opportunities! Also, you rarely feel like just another employee. Sometimes you'll go for a bit without being noticed but the environment allows (and encourages) you to put your ideas out there even if it's not your field.
review.cons: Cons – While management is very smart and generally very competent, leaders seem in short supply. Another concern is how much they try to do in a single year. Objectives and planning are ambitious to say the least. This is not necessarily a bad thing but when they plan more projects than IT resources can handle, you end up with a bottle-neck and a lot of people miss their objectives.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Overstock used to be very engaged in leadership trainings, get your leaders back in to these or some great talent will be wasted in a leadership role. Also, before you plan objectives for the year, take the bottlenecks into account. These bottlenecks include more than just IT. When management has to see and approve everything, they become another hold up.

review.title: “Great people but company headed downhill”
review.pros: Pros – Great people and awesome location if you are into Skiing.
review.cons: Cons – Erratic decision processes at the upper management level and the fear of the 4th quarter
review.advice-to-management: No, I would not recommend this company to a friend

review.title: “This company is set up to fail.”
review.pros: Pros – - Able to learn how to use a wide variety of tools.- Friendly coworkers.- Nice location.- Learn how not to do things.
review.cons: Cons – - Idiotic upper management.- No long term vision.- No clear career path for employees.- Constant reorganizing.- Arbitrary compensation.- Depending on your department, there is no work-life balance.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The lack of a long term vision from upper management is one of the biggest concerns of employees. The executive team doesn't look more than a month or two into the future and appears blind-sided by every new development that arises. Compensation needs to be reevaluated across the company. Too many of the best employees are underpaid, and too many overpaid employees that create no value.

review.title: “Good company with bad communication”
review.pros: Pros – *They will respect you and not treat you as a mindless drone.*Good benefits package. People who say otherwise don't know how bad other companies can be.*They cover internet and phone if you are on call, with an on call differential*Freedom to help build value in the company, for example choosing which projects to prioritize.*Knowing exactly how you made a difference in the company.
review.cons: Cons – *Communication between departments is vague, cryptic and highly political.*Pay disparities. Some people in my same position make 2 times as much as I do if Glassdoor is accurate, but they do the same job I do.*Some people who are afraid to lose their jobs if they let anyone know how to do their job. This leads to poor documentation if there is any at all.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Make communication a company directive. Focus on inter-department communication especially. Create task forces that span several departments and have them meet regularly. Do more evaluation of manager positions and emphasize that feedback is anonymous. Many people think they will get fired if they say something bad on a survey.

review.title: “I am glad I work at Overstock and am grateful for the opportunities they have given me.”
review.pros: Pros – A very diverse work force in a very open work culture makes it almost feel like a university campus - it's great to meet and work with such a group of people. The company has many progressive programs aimed at helping associates improve themselves and their careers. Benefits are excellent and competitive. And the company genuinely cares about morale and making it a place where people want to come to work.I also admiire the philanthropic and charitable personna of our CEO, Dr. Byrne. Programs like World Stock helping people in third world countries make me proud to be an employee.
review.cons: Cons – The company needs to react more quickly to market conditions - and needs to more thoroughly vette its ideas before jumping in with both feet.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Concentrate more on running the business and less on being on every possible Fox business newscast - the business could greatly benefit from your full and undivided attention. The company might then make better decisions, and do so much more quickly than seems possible now.

review.title: “Basically, I love my job.”
review.pros: Pros – For starters, I love the people I work with. There are so many flavors of people here at O.co that I am constantly learning new things about cultures, beliefs and making new friends. I genuinely feel like all coworkers care about my well being in and outside of work. And they all would do almost anything to get me to smile. They make me feel like I am part of something bigger than myself, while not forgetting that I am an individual that has individual needs. That gives me a great reason to come into work each morning. I also have never heard of a company that takes care of their employees so well. From food, to appreciation gifts, to excellent insurance, to 401k benefits, I am always surprised to find a little bit more while I am at work. I also love the responsibilities and challenges that are given me. If I accomplish something well, I feel I am recognized for that and then given additional opportunities to prove myself.
review.cons: Cons – One of the things that surprised me most when I started working here is the hierarchy of the company. Having never worked in corporate environment before, I did not know what I was getting into. Truthfully, it still intimidates me. I would rather feel like the management was more approachable instead of too busy to say hi when they walked through my office.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I feel like there is a disconnect between what happens within each of our buildings, almost as if they were a part of different worlds, not part of the same world. I know what my job is and how it affects our customers, but what does everyone else do, and what impact do they have? How does my job affect them?Also, concerning, my con listed above. As I have gotten to know certain executives, and managers, I have not felt like they were too busy to acknowledge me. So my suggestion is to provide more opportunities for employees to get to know their executives on a personal level.

review.title: “Wealth of Knowledge”
review.pros: Pros – Gain great experience and wealth of knowledge in internet Retail.
review.cons: Cons – Must put in over 40+ hours

review.title: “Used to be a great company. Has declined.”
review.pros: Pros – Laid back environment. Good people to work with
review.cons: Cons – Company has lost focus of core mission and values and is trying to hard to compete with other companies
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Get back to saving people money and not trying to be amazon.

review.title: “It is a resume builder type of company.”
review.pros: Pros – You will be overwhelmed with projects so it is a good resume builder company.
review.cons: Cons – Unless you are in the "in" group you will not go anywhere and you will not be paid for what you are worth.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Be proactive and the executive team should work as a team and not on their own agendas.

review.title: “Overstock.com: Canon Fodder for your Resume--THAT'S ALL THOUGH”
review.pros: Pros – It looks good on a resume... OR at least it did when I left. Being able to work at what appears to be a industry leader for a couple year and make contributions looks good for future employers.
review.cons: Cons – Oh where to begin...1. Senior Management live in their own world completely oblivious to what is going on in reality. They are completely disconnected from the "worker bees" who really make the magic happen.2. You might be an expert in your field, but Senior Management DOES NOT CARE. They are the VP's so they know best in their opinion. Despite most having no formal training or experience in the field they are managing.3. Continuing with the theme, the nepotistic nature of the company, means that if you know someone and suck up enough you might get promoted to a position you hardly deserve. That leaves the rest of us wondering on a daily basis why and how these decision are made.4. You are expected to be perfect. If you make a small mistake you could be fired so that the senior management can make an example, or appear to be handling the situation. This leads to people working in constant fear, and lying when they do make mistakes to avoid being a target. The irony being that if someone at the lowest level makes a mistake, it can be traced to the very top, and the faults of the management being the ultimate culprit.5. On the flip side from #4 Senior management can often make mistakes, some costing the company hundreds of thousands, if not millions of dollars, without any consequence.6. Salaries are far from comparable. Needless to say if you work there or are considering, just look at how much the senior management makes below, and compare that to your salary (that should be a major clue for you): http://bit.ly/pmjWGI7. I could go on, but you get the idea.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – There is no point in giving advice. The ENTIRE senior management team needs to be replaced with people who understand online retail, and can be fiscally responsible to themselves, and their employees. Until then there isn't a lot of hope here.

review.title: “Complete nepotism.”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com is a great company to list on your resume. It will teach you to work in an ever-changing work environment and teach you better time management.
review.cons: Cons – They will tell you there are pay scales for each job, but that is a complete lie and you will have people below you on the hierarchy making a higher salary than you. This is true across the board in every department. Good people leave because Overstock is not willing to compensate or pay the valuable employees.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – My advice to management is to pay your employees based off their job title and competency. Most managers aren't even qualified to be in their positions and you will constantly lose good employees for lack of pay and poor management.

review.title: “O.co is a good company to work for and if you work hard your efforts are appreciated.”
review.pros: Pros – Lots of oppertunity for deserving associates.
review.cons: Cons – Long hours are expected during the holidays.
review.advice-to-management: Yes, I would recommend this company to a friend

review.title: “Overstock is a great place to work, however, stressful.”
review.pros: Pros – O.co has a great culture, however it is a stressful reactive management style
review.cons: Cons – The upper management is overly reactive. The pay is not up to par with industry standards. They expexpect a lot for the little they compensate. There is a huge delta between salaries. Some regulations employees make more than the people managing them
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I would say consistency is key.

review.title: “Miserable. Management is driving it into the ground.”
review.pros: Pros – Pleasant mountain view. Benefits aren't bad.
review.cons: Cons – Management has no idea how to run a company and it is embarrassingly obvious to everyone. They are arrogant, even mean. Expect constant knee-jerk decisions and huge directional changes. Managing by fear and threats is common. You'll fear for your job all the time, which is exhausting and toxic. The company is behind in most areas and is getting lapped by its competition. Talented people leave. It's awful. Don't work here.....you've been warned!
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Where to start? Step aside and hire serious people with legitimate experience.

review.title: “Jumping from one fire to another”
review.pros: Pros – * Good people to work with* Corporate Office is in a nice spot near the canyon
review.cons: Cons – * Salary is below market rate* No raises company wide 2 of the last 3 years, no bonus companywide this year* Projects are given very little ramp up time, which leads to half-done projects and band-aided solutions* All ways chasing the next shiny thing that usually ends up a bust
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Allow for project solutions to be thought out instead of being rushed

review.title: “Great place to work”
review.pros: Pros – Fun relaxing place to work. You can be challenged as much as you want to be. Lots of opportunities to advance within the company. CRAZY CEO!!! (But he's usually right)
review.cons: Cons – Can be high stress depending on the team you are on and your position.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep doing what you're doing.

review.title: “Great”
review.pros: Pros – Good learning culture is one thing that it has.
review.cons: Cons – None that I can think of.
review.advice-to-management: Yes, I would recommend this company to a friend

review.title: “Hostile Work Environment”
review.pros: Pros – Benefits are decent. Could be better, but at least we have them. When you know the right people, management is nice to you. They give you opportunities to grow. Getting time off approved is not a problem. For the most part, management is understanding of your life outside of work.
review.cons: Cons – If you don't know the right people, or if you get on their bad side, work is horrible. Only one member of senior management is actually qualified for their position. None of the other members of management have ever had any actual training, let alone a degree. People with talent at Overstock are downtrodden because management fears they will be replaced by the more qualified individuals. New ideas are shot down, especially if the person is not well liked. Opportunities for growth are based upon personal preference rather than actual abilities. When given the opportunity for growth, no support is given or additional training for skills that would be useful. Good work is almost never recognized and mistakes are blown out of proportion. Communication from management is very poor. Promises are made but never kept. Bottom line, when you have to go into work and fear for your job everyday because of what you did or did not do, it makes for a hostile work environment.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Get some leaders with training, or give the leaders you have training. Foster talent, don't destroy it. Make more decisions based on logic and reason rather than emotion. Respect your employees and then you will gain respect. Be more involved, make time for the people under you. Keep promises and keep perspective.

review.title: “Overstock's downwards spiral”
review.pros: Pros – Lots of focus on customer service. Higher pay than average. Friendly enviroment when you work with people at your same level. Lots of information that can be accessed to help your learn more about various fields of business.
review.cons: Cons – First off the company will give you no privacy even at home. They will micro manage you on a daily basis and even monitor your facebook pages to see what you, your friends and family talk about. Overall the company has been going in a downwards spiral. When you start your employement here you get this idea of this family friendly, understanding, open door enviroment but as you progress throughout the company you gradually learn how untrue that is. A lot of vital information is kept from the employees. Management never gives a straight answer to your questions. Job security is always an issue. The company fires a lot of people every year. Their is a lot of chaos going on behind the veil that they drape over the newer employees. Too much pressure gets put on the frontline reps to improve but no solid answers are given as to what specifically needs to improve. Lots of negative leads and managers. Quality and training seem to have lost touch with the fun and positivity that used to be a major part of their jobs. You will constantly feel stressed at work and it easily effects your home/personal life. If you move up in the company you will get less recognition and be removed from any and all fun activities. People in higher positions deter people from moving up because they are extremely unhappy with their jobs.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Be more prevelant in the workforce. Get new people in management positions. There are a lot of people who have hit the roof for advancement in their careers. As the company grows so should the amount of managers you have running various departments. My advice would be to have 2 managers one over specialty and one over frontline. Get some new faces in management. Provide more incentives accross the board and recognize hardwork more often. The company has always fallen behind in making people feel valued and recognizing it right away. Dont restriict certain employees from the incentives if you allow trainers, qa coaches and leads to get the awards you provide it pushes people to move up in the company and get to that position.

review.title: “Young, inept executives make it a miserable place to work”
review.pros: Pros – There are some very nice people at Overstock.com and a few who actually understand retail and have some experience outside of the company.
review.cons: Cons – Patrick Byrne has insulated himself with a young, inexperienced senior leadership team that has no vision for the future. Decisions are all reactive instead of proactive and the company feels more like a vanity project for Patrick Byrne than a publicly traded company with responsibility to its shareholders. Most people with outside experience end up being unhappy because the company is so poorly managed. Ideas for improving systems, proccesses or structure are not welcome. If you want to keep you job just put your head down and do what you are told even if it is detremental to the business and creates no value for shareholders.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Step back and come up with a realistic vision for the future. Check your ego and learn to show some respect for your employees.

review.title: “Great place for smart people.”
review.pros: Pros – Wow! Working here has really been an experience. The rest of the developers are so smart. I was a big fish in a small pond now I can grow and learn. Everyday is a new challenge and love.
review.cons: Cons – Communication across departments can be a challenge, but I'm sure it's no different than any other company this size.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Don't see upper management much. Would be nice to meet other department heads.

review.title: “Better than average”
review.pros: Pros – Great team to work with.
review.cons: Cons – health benefit and vacation time need improvement
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Good Job.

review.title: “Overstock Rocks!”
review.pros: Pros – Good Benefits. Decent pay. Fun atmosphere. Always busy and never bored. Your co-workers are your friends but treat you more like you are their family.
review.cons: Cons – We are so quick to reply to our customers, but if I ask for time off, I have to wait for a long time to get an answer, and by the time I get the answer to my request, it is sometimes too late. We are the internal customers and we are not treated the same as we would treat an external customer.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Review the time off request procedure. We should have an answer to those requests within a set time frame and shouldn't have to wait FOREVER to get those requests.

review.title: “It's a great place to work”
review.pros: Pros – Good learning opportunities and still growing
review.cons: Cons – high competition in the workplace
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Continue to allow employees to grow

review.title: “Overstock.com is a great place to work”
review.pros: Pros – Great Senior management. They are frequently involved and are supportive of good ideas. The atmosphere is very casual, but intense. They expect excellence and treat their employees well.
review.cons: Cons – They are growing and so space is at a premium. I know they are trying to get more room, but it is painful to try scheduling a meeting or getting some elbow room.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the good work. Continue to trust your employees and grow the company and market share. We have a great product and should keep innovating and moving it forward.

review.title: “Drive to Mediocrity”
review.pros: Pros – Employees have a lot of independence to make meaningful changes to the business.The company culture is very friendly and supportive.Politics are at a minimal.The company is large, but the culture is that of a much smaller company.The growth trajectory makes an very excitingand dynamic time to work at Overstock.com.
review.cons: Cons – Employees with key responsibilities that affect company performance are rarely measured on their actual contribution to the bottom line.The matrix organization allows for multiple hands in each cookie jar, but not every hand is accountable for the best outcome, which makes decision making and execution difficult.Certain processes such as pricing and compensation have a bias towards mediocrity. Outperformers are not appropriately rewarded and sometimes discouraged to meet the norm.Employees tasked with administrative responsibilities are often unmotivated.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Revamp the compensation matrix to measure and appropriately reward each employee's contribution to the company. Company stock should be more liberally rewarded to incentivize and align lower level employees. Align everyone's performance goals with their responsibilities and impact on the company.

review.title: “Good Place to Work”
review.pros: Pros – This is a stable job. People are nice and you get to know everyone you work with. There is a lot of good opportunity you wouldn't get elsehwere.
review.cons: Cons – The pay is a bit low for industry standards and that could be improved i belive. But that is it.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – It would be nice if salaries where a more. It is nice having a job and opportunities here are great.

review.title: “The truth about Overstock”
review.pros: Pros – Over the last couple of years Overstock has had a reasonable work environment. They generally give you time-off when you need it. Most team leads are knowledgeable, and have had a fair about of experience before being promoted to team lead. The company is going fast, I hope they don't grow too fast and not be able to handle the growth with system/backend support. The current benefits are good, but we may be headed down a bad road going forward.
review.cons: Cons – - LOTS of red tape.The good: You go through the process of figuring out your requirements, go through the planning process. Business approves all requirements and design. You start coding and are ready to deploy.The Bad: Along comes architecture/upper IT and they say NO we don't like it. We want you to do it differently.- Not enough hardware and deploy support to handle the number of dev teams in the company.- Interview process and interviewee acceptanceWe want the best there is, but I think we can be slightly less judgmental on who we pick. Allow someone that isn't so set in their ways. We have a very strong development team, so get people that we can work with and help mold them.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – - More hardware and deploy support.- Take the time to get rid of technical debt.- Use the reviews to actually give credit where credit is due.

review.title: “The Pros/Cons to Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock.com is a great place to work,.1) They are open to trying new things.2) They are always trying to stay on the leading edge with their marketing efforts and IT.3) They truly care about their customers, listen to their customers and react to their customers' feedback.4) There is a ton of information available to all employees which empowers them to successfully do their job.5) There is definitely a work hard/ play hard mentality that trickles from the top down.6) There is no tolerance for lying7) Everyone is very open about sharing knowledge.8) From a benefits standpoint, the company does a great job of offering the best they can at a fair price.9) There is a great sense around furthering education in all fields10) There is a sense of balance between life at work and life outside of work.11) Executives do a great job trying to lead by example.I would recommend Overstock.com to anyone as the leaders and employees always strive to do what is right and what is fair for its employees and customers.
review.cons: Cons – 1) There is a very clear separation between departments and collaboration is somewhat limited. In turn, if a merchandising team gets a great deal and purchases it, the marketing team doesn't necessarily create a marketing promotion around it. Instead, marketing creates promotions and appropriate product is then selected.2) There is an incredible "buddy buddy" system at Overstock.com. Like the rest of the world, it's very much about who you know that can help one move within the company.3) The timeframe in which communication spreads throughout the company is weak. In turn, often employees are finding out about key changes at the same time as non-employees which is often after the fact.4) There is some lack of respect for some executives as they seem to know little about what's truly occuring in pieces of the business but have not problems swiftly making changes.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – You make work an enjoyable place to come to each day as there is a sense of family within Overstock.com. Continue to share information to your employees, and they will feel the need to work harder for the company and you. In a 24-7 business, it's hard to slow down and really hear what is going on, but it makes a difference to the person speaking. Speaking and feeling as through your voice is being heard are two different things. You do a great job of listening to our customers and seeking out their feedback. You should try to do a bit more of this internally with employees. Overall, it's a great place to work, and I have/would recommend Overstock.com to those I know and meet.

review.title: “I am not sure what is needed here.”
review.pros: Pros – Overstock prides itself on being a customer service-oriented company that helps consumers save money. The atmosphere is fairly fun and yet professional. On a personal level I look forward to seeing my co-workers and being at work every day. I think my manager and others over me are interested in utilizing my skills and ultimately promoting me.
review.cons: Cons – I've never seen a company that waffles so much on so many issues. Several promises made to me have not been fulfulled. I feel I am not evaluated on all key aspects of my position (and therefore not fairly) and the pay is downright lousy--I cannot live on this entry-level salary, even with roommates.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Listen to what your employees are telling you. Set performance standards at a reasonable level that takes in quality and not just quantity. Think of how each position can benefit the company as a whole, not just as a department. View the website as a consumer would, not as a business person would--see things through customers' eyes. Overall, a lot of you managers rock!

review.title: “Overall”
review.pros: Pros – The people are easy to get along with. Rewards are given to company employees. We can decorate for holidays. Easy to come in to work, some people dred going to work because of various reasons but it is easy to show up every day.
review.cons: Cons – There's not enough parking spaces to accomodate all the employees on a full staff. They end up asking us to move our cars if we're not parked in a valid parking space, and the only other spaces available are on the other side of the building. This is hard to deal with if it's snowing or raining.There is no cieling other than the roof(which is tin) and when it's raining or hailing it's almost too loud to hear the customers.There is not a weatherized smoking area.The dress code is a little too strict for a casual working area. A man is not allowed to wear shorts because they want him to go home and change while a girl is wearing a tank top and flip flops. Even though all of the above are against dress code it should be enforced equally.The stress load can get a little overwhelming around Christmas. I have found myself wishing I could have a vacation to go see my family as they are out of town but I can't as I usually workt he day before and after christmas.Employee Club-O does not give us enough of a discount to be inclined to order from our own website. The 5% discount isn't enough to even cover taxes most times so it's almost like there's no percentage off at all. Free shipping is always good though.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I love working for Overstock.com. Sometimes it is discouraging to submit the employee of the month survey and see the traits of the people that were nominated that do not even surpass the work you do yourself. I also noticed that many of the previous EOMs are people that are not on the phones.When we have Customer Service week I have seen some people winning stuff 2, 3, even 4 times. I feel like my chances are lower if previous winners are still eligible to win again.

review.title: “Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – Decent pay and benefits. Great work environment. VERY diverse staffing. No one is rejected from hire due to race, appearance( tattooes piercings etc) or sexual orientation.
review.cons: Cons – Biggest issue in my opinion is new hires being given "instant" promotions to supervisor ,quality or training positions and people with seniority and who are much better qualified are passed over. It is quite frustrating to those who have been employed here for some time to see people who are brand new and do not know what they are doing put directly into higher positions.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – People should have to be in a front line position for at least 6 months before they are allowed to be on quality ,escalations or any of the specialty teams.

review.title: “Overstock.com - I love working here.”
review.pros: Pros – 1) Exciting work environment. My contributions can quickly be seen in the bottom line of the company.2) Great people. (Truly! I know. I've work at several large companies and Overstock.com has great people. Friendly, professional, knowledgeable and willing to share that knowledge for the good of the company and everyone's professional growth. It's like Google but in Utah.)3) Cool technology == professional satisfaction and growth.
review.cons: Cons – Too long of a waiting period before being able to contribute to 401k program. However, the 401k benefit is generous.What is the waiting period at other companies? Maybe I have a misperception of what constitutes 'too long of a waiting period''?
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I love my job at Overstock.com. It's been a while since I could say that about a place where I've worked. Thank you Overstock.com

review.pros: Pros – The people are very friendly. They are always willing to help eachother. There are a lot of opportunites to move up.
review.cons: Cons – I dont like when you get moved to a specialty team and there is no kind of raise involved. We do A LOT more work than normal CS agents, so I feel even a slightest raise would be appreciated.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Offer a raise when moving up in the company.

review.title: “Interesting place to work.”
review.pros: Pros – Fast changing companyWilling to invest in new technologies.Generally recognizes and rewards good performance
review.cons: Cons – Internal changes are not always well-planned or coordinated.Corporate goals and objectives are not clearly defined and communicated to employees.Sometimes projects are done whichever way is quickest rather than doing them right the first time.Move people around the office too much.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Focus on making the company profitable.Develop a more rigorous process of evaluating projects for ROI before allocating and spending resources on the project.

review.title: “Software tester”
review.pros: Pros – You are given lots of opportunities to learn new tools and receive needed training. I enjoy the flexibility that the teams are given in getting their projects done.
review.cons: Cons – They only have one company party during the year.Trying to get to any of their buildings by public transportation is extremely difficult.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The prediction market program the company has set up in a joke. Everything they want us to predict is a financial question. As a regular employee, I have no idea about the financials of the company. That gives certain people in the company a huge advantage! The worst part is giving the monthly winner a $1000 gift card. Instead of spending the $4600 each month on 20 "special" employees, why not use that money and throw a party for everyone!

review.title: “Satisfied”
review.pros: Pros – Fun and fast-paced! Plenty of work to do - never bored! Relaxed, yet hard-working environment that encourages others to get involved. Management places a lot of trust in the different teams and I feel that encourages active involement on their parts.
review.cons: Cons – Lots of reporting that could be consolidated as well as made more actionable. The on-boarding process for new hires could be more detailed and better illustrated - with all of the vernacular that is unique to Overstock it can be a steep learning curve for some resulting in delayed hiring effectiveness for the company.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Praise in public, Reprimand in private. Small benefits (free lunch, Overstock store, etc) are great! Working in cross-functional teams helps others understand the obstacles and delays experienced in other areas and can too help develop better solutions to these various issues. Most importantly, continue to smile and have fun!! (oh yeah - and a company ski team would be totally rad)

review.title: “Overstock is a good company to work for.”
review.pros: Pros – Coworkers are for the most part friendly and work hard. The people in the analytic portion of the company are very intelligent and are constantly coming up with unique ways of improving the business. The corporate culture is one of smart, casual people that work hard. It is a great company to work for that is on the cutting edge of online retail.
review.cons: Cons – The pay is just okay. I know of many people that are using Overstock as a springboard to gain experience in a tough economy and then planning on moving on to better opportunities as they come available. This is really too bad because it is sad to loose intelligent people and be forced to then have to try to replace them. If Overstock was willing to pay 10-20% more they would hold on to some of these good people and cut down on the replacement costs of having to train someone new.Also, starting with two weeks of PTO (that includes both optional days off and sick days) for your first year is challenging. That increases to three weeks your second year, but most companies start with a minimum of 3 weeks.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Give people a solid reason to stay with Overstock. Make the pay and the benefits such that you not only attract the best people, but hold on to them.

review.title: “Nice place to work”
review.pros: Pros – Good technology culture. Uses cutting edge tools and technology. Not expected to sacrifice my personal life for my job.
review.cons: Cons – Management team still needs some time to mature. Benefits packages could be better.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – None

review.title: “Great place to work.”
review.pros: Pros – Great career opportunities at Overstock.com
review.cons: Cons – Benefits could be a little better
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep doing a great job

review.title: “Overstock.com, a great place to work!”
review.pros: Pros – Promotion from within. Good opportunities to grow professionally. They are always looking at new technologies that can help the company technically and sales wise. Management is in touch with the teams and team members. They really try to make reasonable project schedules and understand that people have lives and families outside of work. Quality of life is one of the best reasons to work at Overstock.com
review.cons: Cons – Parking could be better :)
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the good work.

review.title: “Better management and high salaries, please!”
review.pros: Pros – I have incredible coworkers that I look forward to seeing everydayCasual, laid-back atmosphereLots of contests, parties, raffles and more for employeesGreat benefitsFlexible schedulesGreat locationSenior management makes an effort to get to know everyoneMost of the people in the company are very friendly
review.cons: Cons – Management seems out of touch with employeesPay is significantly lower than what other companies offer for the same positionManagement has little to no knowledge about the jobs their employees doCommunication from management to employees is nonexistent or ambiguous at bestQuestions and concerns addressed to management go unansweredManagement often leaves employees feeling intimidatedManagement has encouraged employees not to report HR problems, saying it is in the employee's best interest, professionally, not to do soGeneral feeling that my department is considered not important to the company, and that the employees therein are expendableLittle to no acknowledgment for a job well doneReceive more attention, praise, etc from management from other departments than from my ownAmbiguous chain of command/ confusing heirarchy organization, including a constant shifting of managers and departmentsEmployees are often shifted about to different desks/rooms, and in some cases are told it is to keep them from getting too comfortableManagement undermining each other's directions, leaving employees confusedMore responsibility is often given without compensationOvertime expectations can become unreasonable during busy times of the yearManagement often makes changes to jobs, departments, etc, even when employees directly inform them that it will be detrimental to work and team morale, such as splitting up teams that work well together, simply to "get them out of their comfort zone"Upper management seems to jump from idea to idea with little follow throughEmployees are given no bigger discount than what is available to the general public
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Employees work their best for the company when they are happy.

review.title: “Don't speak up - or else”
review.pros: Pros – It's close to home, nice atmosphere, not many cubicles where I work. Ummm... the vending machines are nice. There is a water fountani and a river out back.
review.cons: Cons – If you speak up, you will pay for it. The pay sucks compared to other companies of the same size, location, etc. If you want to be promoted, you'd better make sure it comes with more pay, because if you don't, you won't get more pay. They play like they like you, but that's only because you're a "butt" in a seat. One senior Vp who has a stormy name makes a habit of firing people in front of others to make an example of them. She even wanted one employee's parents present at her firing. Are you kidding me?
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I'm afraid to leave advice. I need my job. If I left any sort of negative advice, I am afraid someone would hunt me down and fire me.

review.title: “the big O”
review.pros: Pros – There are some great people here.
review.cons: Cons – The pay is below industry standards.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Let's make 2010 the best year yet.

review.title: “working conditions at Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – diversity, interacting with the customers.
review.cons: Cons – I think there is alot of favortism when trying to move to a new job.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – poor supervisors, there are about 3 that I think are competent

review.title: “This New Year should be awesome!”
review.pros: Pros – The people are great. The benefits are good. The learning of different aspects of the company and its workings, leadership courses, cross training and can’t forget “O” University.
review.cons: Cons – Slow to give rises, promotions, and bonuses went down. Economy has been bad but it's been bad for the regular worker too. With growth in knowledge of all aspects of the workings of the work site and more responsibilities there is a short in matching money with skills and abilities. Hopefully 2010 will be better.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the good work but don't forget those who have been here with you through the good times and hard times. We can be only as great as our advancement allows.

review.title: “Work at Overstock.com”
review.pros: Pros – When I need time off for family obligations I find it very great that I am able to arrange my schedule to be with my family.
review.cons: Cons – I don't feel that the compensation is what is should be for the duties that I perform,
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I think that thing are pretty good as far as managment goes.

review.title: “Great training opportunity's poor physical working conditions.”
review.pros: Pros – The company has been doing an excellent job of providing relevant and useful training. The technologies we use are current and will help improve my useful skill set, and resume. We are working on projects that matter to the company's bottom line which is nice.
review.cons: Cons – Their personal time off/sick pay/holiday pay schedule is very poor, and you cannot accrue more time off with increasing tenure.The physical working conditions are very unprofessional as they are removing all cubicle walls and putting people in rows of desks that are lined up touching side to side back to back. So in the room I work in we will have over 100 people in rows of desks so your desk backs up on some one else's desk and your desk is touching the two desks next to it. We are loosing all of our white boards, which are necessary for working out some software engineering problems. This arrangement would not be bad if you had one small team in a bull pen type area with white boards but when you have over 100 people in a single room with no white boards the noise, and visual distraction level becomes unbearable. This will have the effect of destroying all team communication/colaboration, kill all personal focus and creativity, as people fight constant distractions
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – If you want people to stay, and be productive I would suggest you improve the working conditions, and give people more time off, and allow them to accrue more time off with increasing tenure.

review.title: “Just a job.”
review.pros: Pros – Coworkers are very fun, friendly, and diverse. Products on website are fairly interesting. Frequent hiring because of employee turnover.
review.cons: Cons – Company in general has little respect for employees. Frequent schedule changes with little (1-2 business day) notice. Shared computers with other employees. No personal or secure storage at desk. Everyone in customer service is hired as a temp (no benefits, no holidays) even if you are hired for a specific permanent position. Company won't pay for time it takes for employee to log into computer and log into time keeping website every day. Employees penalized for being sick, even with H1N1 warnings posted everywhere. No employee discount. HR uses only paper employment applications (which they frequently lose).
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Try treating your employees how you want them to treat customers.
